text: JONATHAN HARKER'S JOURNAL
title: Dracula

text: (_Kept in shorthand._)
title: Dracula

text: _3 May. Bistritz._--Left Munich at 8:35 P. M., on 1st May, arriving at
title: Dracula

text: Vienna early next morning; should have arrived at 6:46, but train was an
title: Dracula

text: hour late. Buda-Pesth seems a wonderful place, from the glimpse which I
title: Dracula

text: got of it from the train and the little I could walk through the
title: Dracula

text: streets. I feared to go very far from the station, as we had arrived
title: Dracula

text: late and would start as near the correct time as possible. The
title: Dracula

text: impression I had was that we were leaving the West and entering the
title: Dracula

text: East; the most western of splendid bridges over the Danube, which is
title: Dracula

text: here of noble width and depth, took us among the traditions of Turkish
title: Dracula

text: rule.
title: Dracula

text: We left in pretty good time, and came after nightfall to Klausenburgh.
title: Dracula

text: Here I stopped for the night at the Hotel Royale. I had for dinner, or
title: Dracula

text: rather supper, a chicken done up some way with red pepper, which was
title: Dracula

text: very good but thirsty. (_Mem._, get recipe for Mina.) I asked the
title: Dracula

text: waiter, and he said it was called "paprika hendl," and that, as it was a
title: Dracula

text: national dish, I should be able to get it anywhere along the
title: Dracula

text: Carpathians. I found my smattering of German very useful here; indeed, I
title: Dracula

text: don't know how I should be able to get on without it.
title: Dracula

text: Having had some time at my disposal when in London, I had visited the
title: Dracula

text: British Museum, and made search among the books and maps in the library
title: Dracula

text: regarding Transylvania; it had struck me that some foreknowledge of the
title: Dracula

text: country could hardly fail to have some importance in dealing with a
title: Dracula

text: nobleman of that country. I find that the district he named is in the
title: Dracula

text: extreme east of the country, just on the borders of three states,
title: Dracula

text: Transylvania, Moldavia and Bukovina, in the midst of the Carpathian
title: Dracula

text: mountains; one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe. I was
title: Dracula

text: not able to light on any map or work giving the exact locality of the
title: Dracula

text: Castle Dracula, as there are no maps of this country as yet to compare
title: Dracula

text: with our own Ordnance Survey maps; but I found that Bistritz, the post
title: Dracula

text: town named by Count Dracula, is a fairly well-known place. I shall enter
title: Dracula

text: here some of my notes, as they may refresh my memory when I talk over my
title: Dracula

text: travels with Mina.
title: Dracula

text: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities:
title: Dracula

text: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the
title: Dracula

text: descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the
title: Dracula

text: East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended
title: Dracula

text: from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Magyars conquered
title: Dracula

text: the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I
title: Dracula

text: read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the
title: Dracula

text: horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of
title: Dracula

text: imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (_Mem._, I
title: Dracula

text: must ask the Count all about them.)
title: Dracula

text: I did not sleep well, though my bed was comfortable enough, for I had
title: Dracula

text: all sorts of queer dreams. There was a dog howling all night under my
title: Dracula

text: window, which may have had something to do with it; or it may have been
title: Dracula

text: the paprika, for I had to drink up all the water in my carafe, and was
title: Dracula

text: still thirsty. Towards morning I slept and was wakened by the continuous
title: Dracula

text: knocking at my door, so I guess I must have been sleeping soundly then.
title: Dracula

text: I had for breakfast more paprika, and a sort of porridge of maize flour
title: Dracula

text: which they said was "mamaliga," and egg-plant stuffed with forcemeat, a
title: Dracula

text: very excellent dish, which they call "impletata." (_Mem._, get recipe
title: Dracula

text: for this also.) I had to hurry breakfast, for the train started a little
title: Dracula

text: before eight, or rather it ought to have done so, for after rushing to
title: Dracula

text: the station at 7:30 I had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour
title: Dracula

text: before we began to move. It seems to me that the further east you go the
title: Dracula

text: more unpunctual are the trains. What ought they to be in China?
title: Dracula

text: All day long we seemed to dawdle through a country which was full of
title: Dracula

text: beauty of every kind. Sometimes we saw little towns or castles on the
title: Dracula

text: top of steep hills such as we see in old missals; sometimes we ran by
title: Dracula

text: rivers and streams which seemed from the wide stony margin on each side
title: Dracula

text: of them to be subject to great floods. It takes a lot of water, and
title: Dracula

text: running strong, to sweep the outside edge of a river clear. At every
title: Dracula

text: station there were groups of people, sometimes crowds, and in all sorts
title: Dracula

text: of attire. Some of them were just like the peasants at home or those I
title: Dracula

text: saw coming through France and Germany, with short jackets and round hats
title: Dracula

text: and home-made trousers; but others were very picturesque. The women
title: Dracula

text: looked pretty, except when you got near them, but they were very clumsy
title: Dracula

text: about the waist. They had all full white sleeves of some kind or other,
title: Dracula

text: and most of them had big belts with a lot of strips of something
title: Dracula

text: fluttering from them like the dresses in a ballet, but of course there
title: Dracula

text: were petticoats under them. The strangest figures we saw were the
title: Dracula

text: Slovaks, who were more barbarian than the rest, with their big cow-boy
title: Dracula

text: hats, great baggy dirty-white trousers, white linen shirts, and enormous
title: Dracula

text: heavy leather belts, nearly a foot wide, all studded over with brass
title: Dracula

text: nails. They wore high boots, with their trousers tucked into them, and
title: Dracula

text: had long black hair and heavy black moustaches. They are very
title: Dracula

text: picturesque, but do not look prepossessing. On the stage they would be
title: Dracula

text: set down at once as some old Oriental band of brigands. They are,
title: Dracula

text: however, I am told, very harmless and rather wanting in natural
title: Dracula

text: self-assertion.
title: Dracula

text: It was on the dark side of twilight when we got to Bistritz, which is a
title: Dracula

text: very interesting old place. Being practically on the frontier--for the
title: Dracula

text: Borgo Pass leads from it into Bukovina--it has had a very stormy
title: Dracula

text: existence, and it certainly shows marks of it. Fifty years ago a series
title: Dracula

text: of great fires took place, which made terrible havoc on five separate
title: Dracula

text: occasions. At the very beginning of the seventeenth century it underwent
title: Dracula

text: a siege of three weeks and lost 13,000 people, the casualties of war
title: Dracula

text: proper being assisted by famine and disease.
title: Dracula

text: Count Dracula had directed me to go to the Golden Krone Hotel, which I
title: Dracula

text: found, to my great delight, to be thoroughly old-fashioned, for of
title: Dracula

text: course I wanted to see all I could of the ways of the country. I was
title: Dracula

text: evidently expected, for when I got near the door I faced a
title: Dracula

text: cheery-looking elderly woman in the usual peasant dress--white
title: Dracula

text: undergarment with long double apron, front, and back, of coloured stuff
title: Dracula

text: fitting almost too tight for modesty. When I came close she bowed and
title: Dracula

text: said, "The Herr Englishman?" "Yes," I said, "Jonathan Harker." She
title: Dracula

text: smiled, and gave some message to an elderly man in white shirt-sleeves,
title: Dracula

text: who had followed her to the door. He went, but immediately returned with
title: Dracula

text: a letter:--
title: Dracula

text: "My Friend.--Welcome to the Carpathians. I am anxiously expecting
title: Dracula

text: you. Sleep well to-night. At three to-morrow the diligence will
title: Dracula

text: start for Bukovina; a place on it is kept for you. At the Borgo
title: Dracula

text: Pass my carriage will await you and will bring you to me. I trust
title: Dracula

text: that your journey from London has been a happy one, and that you
title: Dracula

text: will enjoy your stay in my beautiful land.
title: Dracula

text: "Your friend,
title: Dracula

text: "DRACULA."
title: Dracula

text: _4 May._--I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count,
title: Dracula

text: directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on
title: Dracula

text: making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and
title: Dracula

text: pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be
title: Dracula

text: true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he
title: Dracula

text: answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old
title: Dracula

text: lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened sort of
title: Dracula

text: way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that
title: Dracula

text: was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could
title: Dracula

text: tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves,
title: Dracula

text: and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak
title: Dracula

text: further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask
title: Dracula

text: any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means
title: Dracula

text: comforting.
title: Dracula

text: Just before I was leaving, the old lady came up to my room and said in a
title: Dracula

text: very hysterical way:
title: Dracula

text: "Must you go? Oh! young Herr, must you go?" She was in such an excited
title: Dracula

text: state that she seemed to have lost her grip of what German she knew, and
title: Dracula

text: mixed it all up with some other language which I did not know at all. I
title: Dracula

text: was just able to follow her by asking many questions. When I told her
title: Dracula

text: that I must go at once, and that I was engaged on important business,
title: Dracula

text: she asked again:
title: Dracula

text: "Do you know what day it is?" I answered that it was the fourth of May.
title: Dracula

text: She shook her head as she said again:
title: Dracula

text: "Oh, yes! I know that! I know that, but do you know what day it is?" On
title: Dracula

text: my saying that I did not understand, she went on:
title: Dracula

text: "It is the eve of St. George's Day. Do you not know that to-night, when
title: Dracula

text: the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things in the world will have
title: Dracula

text: full sway? Do you know where you are going, and what you are going to?"
title: Dracula

text: She was in such evident distress that I tried to comfort her, but
title: Dracula

text: without effect. Finally she went down on her knees and implored me not
title: Dracula

text: to go; at least to wait a day or two before starting. It was all very
title: Dracula

text: ridiculous but I did not feel comfortable. However, there was business
title: Dracula

text: to be done, and I could allow nothing to interfere with it. I therefore
title: Dracula

text: tried to raise her up, and said, as gravely as I could, that I thanked
title: Dracula

text: her, but my duty was imperative, and that I must go. She then rose and
title: Dracula

text: dried her eyes, and taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me. I
title: Dracula

text: did not know what to do, for, as an English Churchman, I have been
title: Dracula

text: taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet it
title: Dracula

text: seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a
title: Dracula

text: state of mind. She saw, I suppose, the doubt in my face, for she put the
title: Dracula

text: rosary round my neck, and said, "For your mother's sake," and went out
title: Dracula

text: of the room. I am writing up this part of the diary whilst I am waiting
title: Dracula

text: for the coach, which is, of course, late; and the crucifix is still
title: Dracula

text: round my neck. Whether it is the old lady's fear, or the many ghostly
title: Dracula

text: traditions of this place, or the crucifix itself, I do not know, but I
title: Dracula

text: am not feeling nearly as easy in my mind as usual. If this book should
title: Dracula

text: ever reach Mina before I do, let it bring my good-bye. Here comes the
title: Dracula

text: coach!
title: Dracula

text: _5 May. The Castle._--The grey of the morning has passed, and the sun is
title: Dracula

text: high over the distant horizon, which seems jagged, whether with trees or
title: Dracula

text: hills I know not, for it is so far off that big things and little are
title: Dracula

text: mixed. I am not sleepy, and, as I am not to be called till I awake,
title: Dracula

text: naturally I write till sleep comes. There are many odd things to put
title: Dracula

text: down, and, lest who reads them may fancy that I dined too well before I
title: Dracula

text: left Bistritz, let me put down my dinner exactly. I dined on what they
title: Dracula

text: called "robber steak"--bits of bacon, onion, and beef, seasoned with red
title: Dracula

text: pepper, and strung on sticks and roasted over the fire, in the simple
title: Dracula

text: style of the London cat's meat! The wine was Golden Mediasch, which
title: Dracula

text: produces a queer sting on the tongue, which is, however, not
title: Dracula

text: disagreeable. I had only a couple of glasses of this, and nothing else.
title: Dracula

text: When I got on the coach the driver had not taken his seat, and I saw him
title: Dracula

text: talking with the landlady. They were evidently talking of me, for every
title: Dracula

text: now and then they looked at me, and some of the people who were sitting
title: Dracula

text: on the bench outside the door--which they call by a name meaning
title: Dracula

text: "word-bearer"--came and listened, and then looked at me, most of them
title: Dracula

text: pityingly. I could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for
title: Dracula

text: there were many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly got my polyglot
title: Dracula

text: dictionary from my bag and looked them out. I must say they were not
title: Dracula

text: cheering to me, for amongst them were "Ordog"--Satan, "pokol"--hell,
title: Dracula

text: "stregoica"--witch, "vrolok" and "vlkoslak"--both of which mean the same
title: Dracula

text: thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is
title: Dracula

text: either were-wolf or vampire. (_Mem._, I must ask the Count about these
title: Dracula

text: superstitions)
title: Dracula

text: When we started, the crowd round the inn door, which had by this time
title: Dracula

text: swelled to a considerable size, all made the sign of the cross and
title: Dracula

text: pointed two fingers towards me. With some difficulty I got a
title: Dracula

text: fellow-passenger to tell me what they meant; he would not answer at
title: Dracula

text: first, but on learning that I was English, he explained that it was a
title: Dracula

text: charm or guard against the evil eye. This was not very pleasant for me,
title: Dracula

text: just starting for an unknown place to meet an unknown man; but every one
title: Dracula

text: seemed so kind-hearted, and so sorrowful, and so sympathetic that I
title: Dracula

text: could not but be touched. I shall never forget the last glimpse which I
title: Dracula

text: had of the inn-yard and its crowd of picturesque figures, all crossing
title: Dracula

text: themselves, as they stood round the wide archway, with its background of
title: Dracula

text: rich foliage of oleander and orange trees in green tubs clustered in the
title: Dracula

text: centre of the yard. Then our driver, whose wide linen drawers covered
title: Dracula

text: the whole front of the box-seat--"gotza" they call them--cracked his big
title: Dracula

text: whip over his four small horses, which ran abreast, and we set off on
title: Dracula

text: our journey.
title: Dracula

text: I soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the
title: Dracula

text: scene as we drove along, although had I known the language, or rather
title: Dracula

text: languages, which my fellow-passengers were speaking, I might not have
title: Dracula

text: been able to throw them off so easily. Before us lay a green sloping
title: Dracula

text: land full of forests and woods, with here and there steep hills, crowned
title: Dracula

text: with clumps of trees or with farmhouses, the blank gable end to the
title: Dracula

text: road. There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom--apple,
title: Dracula

text: plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under
title: Dracula

text: the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these
title: Dracula

text: green hills of what they call here the "Mittel Land" ran the road,
title: Dracula

text: losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the
title: Dracula

text: straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the
title: Dracula

text: hillsides like tongues of flame. The road was rugged, but still we
title: Dracula

text: seemed to fly over it with a feverish haste. I could not understand then
title: Dracula

text: what the haste meant, but the driver was evidently bent on losing no
title: Dracula

text: time in reaching Borgo Prund. I was told that this road is in summertime
title: Dracula

text: excellent, but that it had not yet been put in order after the winter
title: Dracula

text: snows. In this respect it is different from the general run of roads in
title: Dracula

text: the Carpathians, for it is an old tradition that they are not to be kept
title: Dracula

text: in too good order. Of old the Hospadars would not repair them, lest the
title: Dracula

text: Turk should think that they were preparing to bring in foreign troops,
title: Dracula

text: and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point.
title: Dracula

text: Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel Land rose mighty slopes
title: Dracula

text: of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves. Right
title: Dracula

text: and left of us they towered, with the afternoon sun falling full upon
title: Dracula

text: them and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range,
title: Dracula

text: deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where
title: Dracula

text: grass and rock mingled, and an endless perspective of jagged rock and
title: Dracula

text: pointed crags, till these were themselves lost in the distance, where
title: Dracula

text: the snowy peaks rose grandly. Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the
title: Dracula

text: mountains, through which, as the sun began to sink, we saw now and again
title: Dracula

text: the white gleam of falling water. One of my companions touched my arm as
title: Dracula

text: we swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty, snow-covered
title: Dracula

text: peak of a mountain, which seemed, as we wound on our serpentine way, to
title: Dracula

text: be right before us:--
title: Dracula

text: "Look! Isten szek!"--"God's seat!"--and he crossed himself reverently.
title: Dracula

text: As we wound on our endless way, and the sun sank lower and lower behind
title: Dracula

text: us, the shadows of the evening began to creep round us. This was
title: Dracula

text: emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountain-top still held the
title: Dracula

text: sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink. Here and there
title: Dracula

text: we passed Cszeks and Slovaks, all in picturesque attire, but I noticed
title: Dracula

text: that goitre was painfully prevalent. By the roadside were many crosses,
title: Dracula

text: and as we swept by, my companions all crossed themselves. Here and there
title: Dracula

text: was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine, who did not even
title: Dracula

text: turn round as we approached, but seemed in the self-surrender of
title: Dracula

text: devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world. There were
title: Dracula

text: many things new to me: for instance, hay-ricks in the trees, and here
title: Dracula

text: and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch, their white stems
title: Dracula

text: shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves. Now and
title: Dracula

text: again we passed a leiter-wagon--the ordinary peasant's cart--with its
title: Dracula

text: long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the
title: Dracula

text: road. On this were sure to be seated quite a group of home-coming
title: Dracula

text: peasants, the Cszeks with their white, and the Slovaks with their
title: Dracula

text: coloured, sheepskins, the latter carrying lance-fashion their long
title: Dracula

text: staves, with axe at end. As the evening fell it began to get very cold,
title: Dracula

text: and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the
title: Dracula

text: gloom of the trees, oak, beech, and pine, though in the valleys which
title: Dracula

text: ran deep between the spurs of the hills, as we ascended through the
title: Dracula

text: Pass, the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of
title: Dracula

text: late-lying snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine woods
title: Dracula

text: that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us, great masses of
title: Dracula

text: greyness, which here and there bestrewed the trees, produced a
title: Dracula

text: peculiarly weird and solemn effect, which carried on the thoughts and
title: Dracula

text: grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening, when the falling sunset
title: Dracula

text: threw into strange relief the ghost-like clouds which amongst the
title: Dracula

text: Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys. Sometimes the
title: Dracula

text: hills were so steep that, despite our driver's haste, the horses could
title: Dracula

text: only go slowly. I wished to get down and walk up them, as we do at home,
title: Dracula

text: but the driver would not hear of it. "No, no," he said; "you must not
title: Dracula

text: walk here; the dogs are too fierce"; and then he added, with what he
title: Dracula

text: evidently meant for grim pleasantry--for he looked round to catch the
title: Dracula

text: approving smile of the rest--"and you may have enough of such matters
title: Dracula

text: before you go to sleep." The only stop he would make was a moment's
title: Dracula

text: pause to light his lamps.
title: Dracula

text: When it grew dark there seemed to be some excitement amongst the
title: Dracula

text: passengers, and they kept speaking to him, one after the other, as
title: Dracula

text: though urging him to further speed. He lashed the horses unmercifully
title: Dracula

text: with his long whip, and with wild cries of encouragement urged them on
title: Dracula

text: to further exertions. Then through the darkness I could see a sort of
title: Dracula

text: patch of grey light ahead of us, as though there were a cleft in the
title: Dracula

text: hills. The excitement of the passengers grew greater; the crazy coach
title: Dracula

text: rocked on its great leather springs, and swayed like a boat tossed on a
title: Dracula

text: stormy sea. I had to hold on. The road grew more level, and we appeared
title: Dracula

text: to fly along. Then the mountains seemed to come nearer to us on each
title: Dracula

text: side and to frown down upon us; we were entering on the Borgo Pass. One
title: Dracula

text: by one several of the passengers offered me gifts, which they pressed
title: Dracula

text: upon me with an earnestness which would take no denial; these were
title: Dracula

text: certainly of an odd and varied kind, but each was given in simple good
title: Dracula

text: faith, with a kindly word, and a blessing, and that strange mixture of
title: Dracula

text: fear-meaning movements which I had seen outside the hotel at
title: Dracula

text: Bistritz--the sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye.
title: Dracula

text: Then, as we flew along, the driver leaned forward, and on each side the
title: Dracula

text: passengers, craning over the edge of the coach, peered eagerly into the
title: Dracula

text: darkness. It was evident that something very exciting was either
title: Dracula

text: happening or expected, but though I asked each passenger, no one would
title: Dracula

text: give me the slightest explanation. This state of excitement kept on for
title: Dracula

text: some little time; and at last we saw before us the Pass opening out on
title: Dracula

text: the eastern side. There were dark, rolling clouds overhead, and in the
title: Dracula

text: air the heavy, oppressive sense of thunder. It seemed as though the
title: Dracula

text: mountain range had separated two atmospheres, and that now we had got
title: Dracula

text: into the thunderous one. I was now myself looking out for the conveyance
title: Dracula

text: which was to take me to the Count. Each moment I expected to see the
title: Dracula

text: glare of lamps through the blackness; but all was dark. The only light
title: Dracula

text: was the flickering rays of our own lamps, in which the steam from our
title: Dracula

text: hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud. We could see now the sandy
title: Dracula

text: road lying white before us, but there was on it no sign of a vehicle.
title: Dracula

text: The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness, which seemed to mock
title: Dracula

text: my own disappointment. I was already thinking what I had best do, when
title: Dracula

text: the driver, looking at his watch, said to the others something which I
title: Dracula

text: could hardly hear, it was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone; I
title: Dracula

text: thought it was "An hour less than the time." Then turning to me, he said
title: Dracula

text: in German worse than my own:--
title: Dracula

text: "There is no carriage here. The Herr is not expected after all. He will
title: Dracula

text: now come on to Bukovina, and return to-morrow or the next day; better
title: Dracula

text: the next day." Whilst he was speaking the horses began to neigh and
title: Dracula

text: snort and plunge wildly, so that the driver had to hold them up. Then,
title: Dracula

text: amongst a chorus of screams from the peasants and a universal crossing
title: Dracula

text: of themselves, a calèche, with four horses, drove up behind us, overtook
title: Dracula

text: us, and drew up beside the coach. I could see from the flash of our
title: Dracula

text: lamps, as the rays fell on them, that the horses were coal-black and
title: Dracula

text: splendid animals. They were driven by a tall man, with a long brown
title: Dracula

text: beard and a great black hat, which seemed to hide his face from us. I
title: Dracula

text: could only see the gleam of a pair of very bright eyes, which seemed red
title: Dracula

text: in the lamplight, as he turned to us. He said to the driver:--
title: Dracula

text: "You are early to-night, my friend." The man stammered in reply:--
title: Dracula

text: "The English Herr was in a hurry," to which the stranger replied:--
title: Dracula

text: "That is why, I suppose, you wished him to go on to Bukovina. You cannot
title: Dracula

text: deceive me, my friend; I know too much, and my horses are swift." As he
title: Dracula

text: spoke he smiled, and the lamplight fell on a hard-looking mouth, with
title: Dracula

text: very red lips and sharp-looking teeth, as white as ivory. One of my
title: Dracula

text: companions whispered to another the line from Burger's "Lenore":--
title: Dracula

text: "Denn die Todten reiten schnell"--
title: Dracula

text: ("For the dead travel fast.")
title: Dracula

text: The strange driver evidently heard the words, for he looked up with a
title: Dracula

text: gleaming smile. The passenger turned his face away, at the same time
title: Dracula

text: putting out his two fingers and crossing himself. "Give me the Herr's
title: Dracula

text: luggage," said the driver; and with exceeding alacrity my bags were
title: Dracula

text: handed out and put in the calèche. Then I descended from the side of the
title: Dracula

text: coach, as the calèche was close alongside, the driver helping me with a
title: Dracula

text: hand which caught my arm in a grip of steel; his strength must have been
title: Dracula

text: prodigious. Without a word he shook his reins, the horses turned, and we
title: Dracula

text: swept into the darkness of the Pass. As I looked back I saw the steam
title: Dracula

text: from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps, and projected
title: Dracula

text: against it the figures of my late companions crossing themselves. Then
title: Dracula

text: the driver cracked his whip and called to his horses, and off they swept
title: Dracula

text: on their way to Bukovina. As they sank into the darkness I felt a
title: Dracula

text: strange chill, and a lonely feeling came over me; but a cloak was thrown
title: Dracula

text: over my shoulders, and a rug across my knees, and the driver said in
title: Dracula

text: excellent German:--
title: Dracula

text: "The night is chill, mein Herr, and my master the Count bade me take all
title: Dracula

text: care of you. There is a flask of slivovitz (the plum brandy of the
title: Dracula

text: country) underneath the seat, if you should require it." I did not take
title: Dracula

text: any, but it was a comfort to know it was there all the same. I felt a
title: Dracula

text: little strangely, and not a little frightened. I think had there been
title: Dracula

text: any alternative I should have taken it, instead of prosecuting that
title: Dracula

text: unknown night journey. The carriage went at a hard pace straight along,
title: Dracula

text: then we made a complete turn and went along another straight road. It
title: Dracula

text: seemed to me that we were simply going over and over the same ground
title: Dracula

text: again; and so I took note of some salient point, and found that this was
title: Dracula

text: so. I would have liked to have asked the driver what this all meant, but
title: Dracula

text: I really feared to do so, for I thought that, placed as I was, any
title: Dracula

text: protest would have had no effect in case there had been an intention to
title: Dracula

text: delay. By-and-by, however, as I was curious to know how time was
title: Dracula

text: passing, I struck a match, and by its flame looked at my watch; it was
title: Dracula

text: within a few minutes of midnight. This gave me a sort of shock, for I
title: Dracula

text: suppose the general superstition about midnight was increased by my
title: Dracula

text: recent experiences. I waited with a sick feeling of suspense.
title: Dracula

text: Then a dog began to howl somewhere in a farmhouse far down the road--a
title: Dracula

text: long, agonised wailing, as if from fear. The sound was taken up by
title: Dracula

text: another dog, and then another and another, till, borne on the wind which
title: Dracula

text: now sighed softly through the Pass, a wild howling began, which seemed
title: Dracula

text: to come from all over the country, as far as the imagination could grasp
title: Dracula

text: it through the gloom of the night. At the first howl the horses began to
title: Dracula

text: strain and rear, but the driver spoke to them soothingly, and they
title: Dracula

text: quieted down, but shivered and sweated as though after a runaway from
title: Dracula

text: sudden fright. Then, far off in the distance, from the mountains on each
title: Dracula

text: side of us began a louder and a sharper howling--that of wolves--which
title: Dracula

text: affected both the horses and myself in the same way--for I was minded to
title: Dracula

text: jump from the calèche and run, whilst they reared again and plunged
title: Dracula

text: madly, so that the driver had to use all his great strength to keep them
title: Dracula

text: from bolting. In a few minutes, however, my own ears got accustomed to
title: Dracula

text: the sound, and the horses so far became quiet that the driver was able
title: Dracula

text: to descend and to stand before them. He petted and soothed them, and
title: Dracula

text: whispered something in their ears, as I have heard of horse-tamers
title: Dracula

text: doing, and with extraordinary effect, for under his caresses they became
title: Dracula

text: quite manageable again, though they still trembled. The driver again
title: Dracula

text: took his seat, and shaking his reins, started off at a great pace. This
title: Dracula

text: time, after going to the far side of the Pass, he suddenly turned down a
title: Dracula

text: narrow roadway which ran sharply to the right.
title: Dracula

text: Soon we were hemmed in with trees, which in places arched right over the
title: Dracula

text: roadway till we passed as through a tunnel; and again great frowning
title: Dracula

text: rocks guarded us boldly on either side. Though we were in shelter, we
title: Dracula

text: could hear the rising wind, for it moaned and whistled through the
title: Dracula

text: rocks, and the branches of the trees crashed together as we swept along.
title: Dracula

text: It grew colder and colder still, and fine, powdery snow began to fall,
title: Dracula

text: so that soon we and all around us were covered with a white blanket. The
title: Dracula

text: keen wind still carried the howling of the dogs, though this grew
title: Dracula

text: fainter as we went on our way. The baying of the wolves sounded nearer
title: Dracula

text: and nearer, as though they were closing round on us from every side. I
title: Dracula

text: grew dreadfully afraid, and the horses shared my fear. The driver,
title: Dracula

text: however, was not in the least disturbed; he kept turning his head to
title: Dracula

text: left and right, but I could not see anything through the darkness.
title: Dracula

text: Suddenly, away on our left, I saw a faint flickering blue flame. The
title: Dracula

text: driver saw it at the same moment; he at once checked the horses, and,
title: Dracula

text: jumping to the ground, disappeared into the darkness. I did not know
title: Dracula

text: what to do, the less as the howling of the wolves grew closer; but while
title: Dracula

text: I wondered the driver suddenly appeared again, and without a word took
title: Dracula

text: his seat, and we resumed our journey. I think I must have fallen asleep
title: Dracula

text: and kept dreaming of the incident, for it seemed to be repeated
title: Dracula

text: endlessly, and now looking back, it is like a sort of awful nightmare.
title: Dracula

text: Once the flame appeared so near the road, that even in the darkness
title: Dracula

text: around us I could watch the driver's motions. He went rapidly to where
title: Dracula

text: the blue flame arose--it must have been very faint, for it did not seem
title: Dracula

text: to illumine the place around it at all--and gathering a few stones,
title: Dracula

text: formed them into some device. Once there appeared a strange optical
title: Dracula

text: effect: when he stood between me and the flame he did not obstruct it,
title: Dracula

text: for I could see its ghostly flicker all the same. This startled me, but
title: Dracula

text: as the effect was only momentary, I took it that my eyes deceived me
title: Dracula

text: straining through the darkness. Then for a time there were no blue
title: Dracula

text: flames, and we sped onwards through the gloom, with the howling of the
title: Dracula

text: wolves around us, as though they were following in a moving circle.
title: Dracula

text: At last there came a time when the driver went further afield than he
title: Dracula

text: had yet gone, and during his absence, the horses began to tremble worse
title: Dracula

text: than ever and to snort and scream with fright. I could not see any cause
title: Dracula

text: for it, for the howling of the wolves had ceased altogether; but just
title: Dracula

text: then the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the
title: Dracula

text: jagged crest of a beetling, pine-clad rock, and by its light I saw
title: Dracula

text: around us a ring of wolves, with white teeth and lolling red tongues,
title: Dracula

text: with long, sinewy limbs and shaggy hair. They were a hundred times more
title: Dracula

text: terrible in the grim silence which held them than even when they howled.
title: Dracula

text: For myself, I felt a sort of paralysis of fear. It is only when a man
title: Dracula

text: feels himself face to face with such horrors that he can understand
title: Dracula

text: their true import.
title: Dracula

text: All at once the wolves began to howl as though the moonlight had had
title: Dracula

text: some peculiar effect on them. The horses jumped about and reared, and
title: Dracula

text: looked helplessly round with eyes that rolled in a way painful to see;
title: Dracula

text: but the living ring of terror encompassed them on every side; and they
title: Dracula

text: had perforce to remain within it. I called to the coachman to come, for
title: Dracula

text: it seemed to me that our only chance was to try to break out through the
title: Dracula

text: ring and to aid his approach. I shouted and beat the side of the
title: Dracula

text: calèche, hoping by the noise to scare the wolves from that side, so as
title: Dracula

text: to give him a chance of reaching the trap. How he came there, I know
title: Dracula

text: not, but I heard his voice raised in a tone of imperious command, and
title: Dracula

text: looking towards the sound, saw him stand in the roadway. As he swept his
title: Dracula

text: long arms, as though brushing aside some impalpable obstacle, the wolves
title: Dracula

text: fell back and back further still. Just then a heavy cloud passed across
title: Dracula

text: the face of the moon, so that we were again in darkness.
title: Dracula

text: When I could see again the driver was climbing into the calèche, and the
title: Dracula

text: wolves had disappeared. This was all so strange and uncanny that a
title: Dracula

text: dreadful fear came upon me, and I was afraid to speak or move. The time
title: Dracula

text: seemed interminable as we swept on our way, now in almost complete
title: Dracula

text: darkness, for the rolling clouds obscured the moon. We kept on
title: Dracula

text: ascending, with occasional periods of quick descent, but in the main
title: Dracula

text: always ascending. Suddenly, I became conscious of the fact that the
title: Dracula

text: driver was in the act of pulling up the horses in the courtyard of a
title: Dracula

text: vast ruined castle, from whose tall black windows came no ray of light,
title: Dracula

text: and whose broken battlements showed a jagged line against the moonlit
title: Dracula

text: sky.
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER II
title: Dracula

text: JONATHAN HARKER'S JOURNAL--_continued_
title: Dracula

text: _5 May._--I must have been asleep, for certainly if I had been fully
title: Dracula

text: awake I must have noticed the approach of such a remarkable place. In
title: Dracula

text: the gloom the courtyard looked of considerable size, and as several dark
title: Dracula

text: ways led from it under great round arches, it perhaps seemed bigger than
title: Dracula

text: it really is. I have not yet been able to see it by daylight.
title: Dracula

text: When the calèche stopped, the driver jumped down and held out his hand
title: Dracula

text: to assist me to alight. Again I could not but notice his prodigious
title: Dracula

text: strength. His hand actually seemed like a steel vice that could have
title: Dracula

text: crushed mine if he had chosen. Then he took out my traps, and placed
title: Dracula

text: them on the ground beside me as I stood close to a great door, old and
title: Dracula

text: studded with large iron nails, and set in a projecting doorway of
title: Dracula

text: massive stone. I could see even in the dim light that the stone was
title: Dracula

text: massively carved, but that the carving had been much worn by time and
title: Dracula

text: weather. As I stood, the driver jumped again into his seat and shook the
title: Dracula

text: reins; the horses started forward, and trap and all disappeared down one
title: Dracula

text: of the dark openings.
title: Dracula

text: I stood in silence where I was, for I did not know what to do. Of bell
title: Dracula

text: or knocker there was no sign; through these frowning walls and dark
title: Dracula

text: window openings it was not likely that my voice could penetrate. The
title: Dracula

text: time I waited seemed endless, and I felt doubts and fears crowding upon
title: Dracula

text: me. What sort of place had I come to, and among what kind of people?
title: Dracula

text: What sort of grim adventure was it on which I had embarked? Was this a
title: Dracula

text: customary incident in the life of a solicitor's clerk sent out to
title: Dracula

text: explain the purchase of a London estate to a foreigner? Solicitor's
title: Dracula

text: clerk! Mina would not like that. Solicitor--for just before leaving
title: Dracula

text: London I got word that my examination was successful; and I am now a
title: Dracula

text: full-blown solicitor! I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself to see if
title: Dracula

text: I were awake. It all seemed like a horrible nightmare to me, and I
title: Dracula

text: expected that I should suddenly awake, and find myself at home, with
title: Dracula

text: the dawn struggling in through the windows, as I had now and again felt
title: Dracula

text: in the morning after a day of overwork. But my flesh answered the
title: Dracula

text: pinching test, and my eyes were not to be deceived. I was indeed awake
title: Dracula

text: and among the Carpathians. All I could do now was to be patient, and to
title: Dracula

text: wait the coming of the morning.
title: Dracula

text: Just as I had come to this conclusion I heard a heavy step approaching
title: Dracula

text: behind the great door, and saw through the chinks the gleam of a coming
title: Dracula

text: light. Then there was the sound of rattling chains and the clanking of
title: Dracula

text: massive bolts drawn back. A key was turned with the loud grating noise
title: Dracula

text: of long disuse, and the great door swung back.
title: Dracula

text: Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white
title: Dracula

text: moustache, and clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck
title: Dracula

text: of colour about him anywhere. He held in his hand an antique silver
title: Dracula

text: lamp, in which the flame burned without chimney or globe of any kind,
title: Dracula

text: throwing long quivering shadows as it flickered in the draught of the
title: Dracula

text: open door. The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly
title: Dracula

text: gesture, saying in excellent English, but with a strange intonation:--
title: Dracula

text: "Welcome to my house! Enter freely and of your own will!" He made no
title: Dracula

text: motion of stepping to meet me, but stood like a statue, as though his
title: Dracula

text: gesture of welcome had fixed him into stone. The instant, however, that
title: Dracula

text: I had stepped over the threshold, he moved impulsively forward, and
title: Dracula

text: holding out his hand grasped mine with a strength which made me wince,
title: Dracula

text: an effect which was not lessened by the fact that it seemed as cold as
title: Dracula

text: ice--more like the hand of a dead than a living man. Again he said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Welcome to my house. Come freely. Go safely; and leave something of the
title: Dracula

text: happiness you bring!" The strength of the handshake was so much akin to
title: Dracula

text: that which I had noticed in the driver, whose face I had not seen, that
title: Dracula

text: for a moment I doubted if it were not the same person to whom I was
title: Dracula

text: speaking; so to make sure, I said interrogatively:--
title: Dracula

text: "Count Dracula?" He bowed in a courtly way as he replied:--
title: Dracula

text: "I am Dracula; and I bid you welcome, Mr. Harker, to my house. Come in;
title: Dracula

text: the night air is chill, and you must need to eat and rest." As he was
title: Dracula

text: speaking, he put the lamp on a bracket on the wall, and stepping out,
title: Dracula

text: took my luggage; he had carried it in before I could forestall him. I
title: Dracula

text: protested but he insisted:--
title: Dracula

text: "Nay, sir, you are my guest. It is late, and my people are not
title: Dracula

text: available. Let me see to your comfort myself." He insisted on carrying
title: Dracula

text: my traps along the passage, and then up a great winding stair, and
title: Dracula

text: along another great passage, on whose stone floor our steps rang
title: Dracula

text: heavily. At the end of this he threw open a heavy door, and I rejoiced
title: Dracula

text: to see within a well-lit room in which a table was spread for supper,
title: Dracula

text: and on whose mighty hearth a great fire of logs, freshly replenished,
title: Dracula

text: flamed and flared.
title: Dracula

text: The Count halted, putting down my bags, closed the door, and crossing
title: Dracula

text: the room, opened another door, which led into a small octagonal room lit
title: Dracula

text: by a single lamp, and seemingly without a window of any sort. Passing
title: Dracula

text: through this, he opened another door, and motioned me to enter. It was a
title: Dracula

text: welcome sight; for here was a great bedroom well lighted and warmed with
title: Dracula

text: another log fire,--also added to but lately, for the top logs were
title: Dracula

text: fresh--which sent a hollow roar up the wide chimney. The Count himself
title: Dracula

text: left my luggage inside and withdrew, saying, before he closed the
title: Dracula

text: door:--
title: Dracula

text: "You will need, after your journey, to refresh yourself by making your
title: Dracula

text: toilet. I trust you will find all you wish. When you are ready, come
title: Dracula

text: into the other room, where you will find your supper prepared."
title: Dracula

text: The light and warmth and the Count's courteous welcome seemed to have
title: Dracula

text: dissipated all my doubts and fears. Having then reached my normal state,
title: Dracula

text: I discovered that I was half famished with hunger; so making a hasty
title: Dracula

text: toilet, I went into the other room.
title: Dracula

text: I found supper already laid out. My host, who stood on one side of the
title: Dracula

text: great fireplace, leaning against the stonework, made a graceful wave of
title: Dracula

text: his hand to the table, and said:--
title: Dracula

text: "I pray you, be seated and sup how you please. You will, I trust, excuse
title: Dracula

text: me that I do not join you; but I have dined already, and I do not sup."
title: Dracula

text: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr. Hawkins had entrusted to me.
title: Dracula

text: He opened it and read it gravely; then, with a charming smile, he handed
title: Dracula

text: it to me to read. One passage of it, at least, gave me a thrill of
title: Dracula

text: pleasure.
title: Dracula

text: "I must regret that an attack of gout, from which malady I am a constant
title: Dracula

text: sufferer, forbids absolutely any travelling on my part for some time to
title: Dracula

text: come; but I am happy to say I can send a sufficient substitute, one in
title: Dracula

text: whom I have every possible confidence. He is a young man, full of energy
title: Dracula

text: and talent in his own way, and of a very faithful disposition. He is
title: Dracula

text: discreet and silent, and has grown into manhood in my service. He shall
title: Dracula

text: be ready to attend on you when you will during his stay, and shall take
title: Dracula

text: your instructions in all matters."
title: Dracula

text: The Count himself came forward and took off the cover of a dish, and I
title: Dracula

text: fell to at once on an excellent roast chicken. This, with some cheese
title: Dracula

text: and a salad and a bottle of old Tokay, of which I had two glasses, was
title: Dracula

text: my supper. During the time I was eating it the Count asked me many
title: Dracula

text: questions as to my journey, and I told him by degrees all I had
title: Dracula

text: experienced.
title: Dracula

text: By this time I had finished my supper, and by my host's desire had drawn
title: Dracula

text: up a chair by the fire and begun to smoke a cigar which he offered me,
title: Dracula

text: at the same time excusing himself that he did not smoke. I had now an
title: Dracula

text: opportunity of observing him, and found him of a very marked
title: Dracula

text: physiognomy.
title: Dracula

text: His face was a strong--a very strong--aquiline, with high bridge of the
title: Dracula

text: thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils; with lofty domed forehead, and
title: Dracula

text: hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere. His
title: Dracula

text: eyebrows were very massive, almost meeting over the nose, and with bushy
title: Dracula

text: hair that seemed to curl in its own profusion. The mouth, so far as I
title: Dracula

text: could see it under the heavy moustache, was fixed and rather
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: When I found that I was a prisoner a sort of wild feeling came over me.
title: Dracula

text: I rushed up and down the stairs, trying every door and peering out of
title: Dracula

text: every window I could find; but after a little the conviction of my
title: Dracula

text: helplessness overpowered all other feelings. When I look back after a
title: Dracula

text: few hours I think I must have been mad for the time, for I behaved much
title: Dracula

text: as a rat does in a trap. When, however, the conviction had come to me
title: Dracula

text: that I was helpless I sat down quietly--as quietly as I have ever done
title: Dracula

text: anything in my life--and began to think over what was best to be done. I
title: Dracula

text: am thinking still, and as yet have come to no definite conclusion. Of
title: Dracula

text: one thing only am I certain; that it is no use making my ideas known to
title: Dracula

text: the Count. He knows well that I am imprisoned; and as he has done it
title: Dracula

text: himself, and has doubtless his own motives for it, he would only deceive
title: Dracula

text: me if I trusted him fully with the facts. So far as I can see, my only
title: Dracula

text: plan will be to keep my knowledge and my fears to myself, and my eyes
title: Dracula

text: open. I am, I know, either being deceived, like a baby, by my own fears,
title: Dracula

text: or else I am in desperate straits; and if the latter be so, I need, and
title: Dracula

text: shall need, all my brains to get through.
title: Dracula

text: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below
title: Dracula

text: shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into
title: Dracula

text: the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making
title: Dracula

text: the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along
title: Dracula

text: thought--that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him
title: Dracula

text: through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the
title: Dracula

text: dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these
title: Dracula

text: menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them.
title: Dracula

text: This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it
title: Dracula

text: must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that
title: Dracula

text: brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it
title: Dracula

text: mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his
title: Dracula

text: hand in silence. How was it that all the people at Bistritz and on the
title: Dracula

text: coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the
title: Dracula

text: crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless
title: Dracula

text: that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a
title: Dracula

text: comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing
title: Dracula

text: which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous
title: Dracula

text: should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there
title: Dracula

text: is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium,
title: Dracula

text: a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some
title: Dracula

text: time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my
title: Dracula

text: mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count
title: Dracula

text: Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of
title: Dracula

text: himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful,
title: Dracula

text: however, not to awake his suspicion.

text: _Midnight._--I have had a long talk with the Count. I asked him a few
title: Dracula

text: questions on Transylvania history, and he warmed up to the subject
title: Dracula

text: wonderfully. In his speaking of things and people, and especially of
title: Dracula

text: battles, he spoke as if he had been present at them all. This he
title: Dracula

text: afterwards explained by saying that to a _boyar_ the pride of his house
title: Dracula

text: and name is his own pride, that their glory is his glory, that their
title: Dracula

text: fate is his fate. Whenever he spoke of his house he always said "we,"
title: Dracula

text: and spoke almost in the plural, like a king speaking. I wish I could put
title: Dracula

text: down all he said exactly as he said it, for to me it was most
title: Dracula

text: fascinating. It seemed to have in it a whole history of the country. He
title: Dracula

text: grew excited as he spoke, and walked about the room pulling his great
title: Dracula

text: white moustache and grasping anything on which he laid his hands as
title: Dracula

text: though he would crush it by main strength. One thing he said which I
title: Dracula

text: shall put down as nearly as I can; for it tells in its way the story of
title: Dracula

text: his race:--
title: Dracula

text: "We Szekelys have a right to be proud, for in our veins flows the blood
title: Dracula

text: of many brave races who fought as the lion fights, for lordship. Here,
title: Dracula

text: in the whirlpool of European races, the Ugric tribe bore down from
title: Dracula

text: Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and Wodin gave them, which their
title: Dracula

text: Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of Europe, ay,
title: Dracula

text: and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that the
title: Dracula

text: were-wolves themselves had come. Here, too, when they came, they found
title: Dracula

text: the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame,
title: Dracula

text: till the dying peoples held that in their veins ran the blood of those
title: Dracula

text: old witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the
title: Dracula

text: desert. Fools, fools! What devil or what witch was ever so great as
title: Dracula

text: Attila, whose blood is in these veins?" He held up his arms. "Is it a
title: Dracula

text: wonder that we were a conquering race; that we were proud; that when the
title: Dracula

text: Magyar, the Lombard, the Avar, the Bulgar, or the Turk poured his
title: Dracula

text: thousands on our frontiers, we drove them back? Is it strange that when
title: Dracula

text: Arpad and his legions swept through the Hungarian fatherland he found us
title: Dracula

text: here when he reached the frontier; that the Honfoglalas was completed
title: Dracula

text: there? And when the Hungarian flood swept eastward, the Szekelys were
title: Dracula

text: claimed as kindred by the victorious Magyars, and to us for centuries
title: Dracula

text: was trusted the guarding of the frontier of Turkey-land; ay, and more
title: Dracula

text: than that, endless duty of the frontier guard, for, as the Turks say,
title: Dracula

text: 'water sleeps, and enemy is sleepless.' Who more gladly than we
title: Dracula

text: throughout the Four Nations received the 'bloody sword,' or at its
title: Dracula

text: warlike call flocked quicker to the standard of the King? When was
title: Dracula

text: redeemed that great shame of my nation, the shame of Cassova, when the
title: Dracula

text: flags of the Wallach and the Magyar went down beneath the Crescent? Who
title: Dracula

text: was it but one of my own race who as Voivode crossed the Danube and beat
title: Dracula

text: the Turk on his own ground? This was a Dracula indeed! Woe was it that
title: Dracula

text: his own unworthy brother, when he had fallen, sold his people to the
title: Dracula

text: Turk and brought the shame of slavery on them! Was it not this Dracula,
title: Dracula

text: indeed, who inspired that other of his race who in a later age again and
title: Dracula

text: again brought his forces over the great river into Turkey-land; who,
title: Dracula

text: when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had
title: Dracula

text: to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being
title: Dracula

text: slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph! They
title: Dracula

text: said that he thought only of himself. Bah! what good are peasants
title: Dracula

text: without a leader? Where ends the war without a brain and heart to
title: Dracula

text: conduct it? Again, when, after the battle of Mohács, we threw off the
title: Dracula

text: Hungarian yoke, we of the Dracula blood were amongst their leaders, for
title: Dracula

text: our spirit would not brook that we were not free. Ah, young sir, the
title: Dracula

text: Szekelys--and the Dracula as their heart's blood, their brains, and
title: Dracula

text: their swords--can boast a record that mushroom growths like the
title: Dracula

text: Hapsburgs and the Romanoffs can never reach. The warlike days are over.
title: Dracula

text: Blood is too precious a thing in these days of dishonourable peace; and
title: Dracula

text: the glories of the great races are as a tale that is told."

text: _12 May._--Let me begin with facts--bare, meagre facts, verified by
title: Dracula

text: books and figures, and of which there can be no doubt. I must not
title: Dracula

text: confuse them with experiences which will have to rest on my own
title: Dracula

text: observation, or my memory of them. Last evening when the Count came from
title: Dracula

text: his room he began by asking me questions on legal matters and on the
title: Dracula

text: doing of certain kinds of business. I had spent the day wearily over
title: Dracula

text: books, and, simply to keep my mind occupied, went over some of the
title: Dracula

text: matters I had been examining at Lincoln's Inn. There was a certain
title: Dracula

text: method in the Count's inquiries, so I shall try to put them down in
title: Dracula

text: sequence; the knowledge may somehow or some time be useful to me.
title: Dracula

text: First, he asked if a man in England might have two solicitors or more. I
title: Dracula

text: told him he might have a dozen if he wished, but that it would not be
title: Dracula

text: wise to have more than one solicitor engaged in one transaction, as only
title: Dracula

text: one could act at a time, and that to change would be certain to militate
title: Dracula

text: against his interest. He seemed thoroughly to understand, and went on to
title: Dracula

text: ask if there would be any practical difficulty in having one man to
title: Dracula

text: attend, say, to banking, and another to look after shipping, in case
title: Dracula

text: local help were needed in a place far from the home of the banking
title: Dracula

text: solicitor. I asked him to explain more fully, so that I might not by any
title: Dracula

text: chance mislead him, so he said:--
title: Dracula

text: "I shall illustrate. Your friend and mine, Mr. Peter Hawkins, from under
title: Dracula

text: the shadow of your beautiful cathedral at Exeter, which is far from
title: Dracula

text: London, buys for me through your good self my place at London. Good! Now
title: Dracula

text: here let me say frankly, lest you should think it strange that I have
title: Dracula

text: sought the services of one so far off from London instead of some one
title: Dracula

text: resident there, that my motive was that no local interest might be
title: Dracula

text: served save my wish only; and as one of London residence might, perhaps,
title: Dracula

text: have some purpose of himself or friend to serve, I went thus afield to
title: Dracula

text: seek my agent, whose labours should be only to my interest. Now, suppose
title: Dracula

text: I, who have much of affairs, wish to ship goods, say, to Newcastle, or
title: Dracula

text: Durham, or Harwich, or Dover, might it not be that it could with more
title: Dracula

text: ease be done by consigning to one in these ports?" I answered that
title: Dracula

text: certainly it would be most easy, but that we solicitors had a system of
title: Dracula

text: agency one for the other, so that local work could be done locally on
title: Dracula

text: instruction from any solicitor, so that the client, simply placing
title: Dracula

text: himself in the hands of one man, could have his wishes carried out by
title: Dracula

text: him without further trouble.
title: Dracula

text: "But," said he, "I could be at liberty to direct myself. Is it not so?"
title: Dracula

text: "Of course," I replied; and "such is often done by men of business, who
title: Dracula

text: do not like the whole of their affairs to be known by any one person."
title: Dracula

text: "Good!" he said, and then went on to ask about the means of making
title: Dracula

text: consignments and the forms to be gone through, and of all sorts of
title: Dracula

text: difficulties which might arise, but by forethought could be guarded
title: Dracula

text: against. I explained all these things to him to the best of my ability,
title: Dracula

text: and he certainly left me under the impression that he would have made a
title: Dracula

text: wonderful solicitor, for there was nothing that he did not think of or
title: Dracula

text: foresee. For a man who was never in the country, and who did not
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: spoken, and I had verified all as well as I could by the books
title: Dracula

text: available, he suddenly stood up and said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Have you written since your first letter to our friend Mr. Peter
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: I answered that I had not, that as yet I had not seen any opportunity of
title: Dracula

text: sending letters to anybody.
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: shoulder: "write to our friend and to any other; and say, if it will
title: Dracula

text: please you, that you shall stay with me until a month from now."
title: Dracula

text: "Do you wish me to stay so long?" I asked, for my heart grew cold at the
title: Dracula

text: thought.
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: employer, what you will, engaged that someone should come on his behalf,
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: in his own smooth, resistless way:--
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: understand the man. He has certain qualities very largely developed;
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _Mina Murray's Journal._
title: Dracula

text: _26 July._--I am anxious, and it soothes me to express myself here; it
title: Dracula

text: is like whispering to one's self and listening at the same time. And
title: Dracula

text: there is also something about the shorthand symbols that makes it
title: Dracula

text: different from writing. I am unhappy about Lucy and about Jonathan. I
title: Dracula

text: had not heard from Jonathan for some time, and was very concerned; but
title: Dracula

text: yesterday dear Mr. Hawkins, who is always so kind, sent me a letter from
title: Dracula

text: him. I had written asking him if he had heard, and he said the enclosed
title: Dracula

text: had just been received. It is only a line dated from Castle Dracula,
title: Dracula

text: and says that he is just starting for home. That is not like Jonathan;
title: Dracula

text: I do not understand it, and it makes me uneasy. Then, too, Lucy,
title: Dracula

text: although she is so well, has lately taken to her old habit of walking in
title: Dracula

text: her sleep. Her mother has spoken to me about it, and we have decided
title: Dracula

text: that I am to lock the door of our room every night. Mrs. Westenra has
title: Dracula

text: got an idea that sleep-walkers always go out on roofs of houses and
title: Dracula

text: along the edges of cliffs and then get suddenly wakened and fall over
title: Dracula

text: with a despairing cry that echoes all over the place. Poor dear, she is
title: Dracula

text: naturally anxious about Lucy, and she tells me that her husband, Lucy's
title: Dracula

text: father, had the same habit; that he would get up in the night and dress
title: Dracula

text: himself and go out, if he were not stopped. Lucy is to be married in the
title: Dracula

text: autumn, and she is already planning out her dresses and how her house is
title: Dracula

text: to be arranged. I sympathise with her, for I do the same, only Jonathan
title: Dracula

text: and I will start in life in a very simple way, and shall have to try to
title: Dracula

text: make both ends meet. Mr. Holmwood--he is the Hon. Arthur Holmwood, only
title: Dracula

text: son of Lord Godalming--is coming up here very shortly--as soon as he can
title: Dracula

text: leave town, for his father is not very well, and I think dear Lucy is
title: Dracula

text: counting the moments till he comes. She wants to take him up to the seat
title: Dracula

text: on the churchyard cliff and show him the beauty of Whitby. I daresay it
title: Dracula

text: is the waiting which disturbs her; she will be all right when he
title: Dracula

text: arrives.
title: Dracula

text: _27 July._--No news from Jonathan. I am getting quite uneasy about him,
title: Dracula

text: though why I should I do not know; but I do wish that he would write, if
title: Dracula

text: it were only a single line. Lucy walks more than ever, and each night I
title: Dracula

text: am awakened by her moving about the room. Fortunately, the weather is so
title: Dracula

text: hot that she cannot get cold; but still the anxiety and the perpetually
title: Dracula

text: being wakened is beginning to tell on me, and I am getting nervous and
title: Dracula

text: wakeful myself. Thank God, Lucy's health keeps up. Mr. Holmwood has been
title: Dracula

text: suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has been taken seriously
title: Dracula

text: ill. Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him, but it does not touch
title: Dracula

text: her looks; she is a trifle stouter, and her cheeks are a lovely
title: Dracula

text: rose-pink. She has lost that anæmic look which she had. I pray it will
title: Dracula

text: all last.
title: Dracula

text: _3 August._--Another week gone, and no news from Jonathan, not even to
title: Dracula

text: Mr. Hawkins, from whom I have heard. Oh, I do hope he is not ill. He
title: Dracula

text: surely would have written. I look at that last letter of his, but
title: Dracula

text: somehow it does not satisfy me. It does not read like him, and yet it is
title: Dracula

text: his writing. There is no mistake of that. Lucy has not walked much in
title: Dracula

text: her sleep the last week, but there is an odd concentration about her
title: Dracula

text: which I do not understand; even in her sleep she seems to be watching
title: Dracula

text: me. She tries the door, and finding it locked, goes about the room
title: Dracula

text: searching for the key.
title: Dracula

text: _6 August._--Another three days, and no news. This suspense is getting
title: Dracula

text: dreadful. If I only knew where to write to or where to go to, I should
title: Dracula

text: feel easier; but no one has heard a word of Jonathan since that last
title: Dracula

text: letter. I must only pray to God for patience. Lucy is more excitable
title: Dracula

text: than ever, but is otherwise well. Last night was very threatening, and
title: Dracula

text: the fishermen say that we are in for a storm. I must try to watch it and
title: Dracula

text: learn the weather signs. To-day is a grey day, and the sun as I write is
title: Dracula

text: hidden in thick clouds, high over Kettleness. Everything is grey--except
title: Dracula

text: the green grass, which seems like emerald amongst it; grey earthy rock;
title: Dracula

text: grey clouds, tinged with the sunburst at the far edge, hang over the
title: Dracula

text: grey sea, into which the sand-points stretch like grey fingers. The sea
title: Dracula

text: is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar,
title: Dracula

text: muffled in the sea-mists drifting inland. The horizon is lost in a grey
title: Dracula

text: mist. All is vastness; the clouds are piled up like giant rocks, and
title: Dracula

text: there is a "brool" over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom.
title: Dracula

text: Dark figures are on the beach here and there, sometimes half shrouded in
title: Dracula

text: the mist, and seem "men like trees walking." The fishing-boats are
title: Dracula

text: racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into
title: Dracula

text: the harbour, bending to the scuppers. Here comes old Mr. Swales. He is
title: Dracula

text: making straight for me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that
title: Dracula

text: he wants to talk....
title: Dracula

text: I have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man. When he sat
title: Dracula

text: down beside me, he said in a very gentle way:--
title: Dracula

text: "I want to say something to you, miss." I could see he was not at ease,
title: Dracula

text: so I took his poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak
title: Dracula

text: fully; so he said, leaving his hand in mine:--
title: Dracula

text: "I'm afraid, my deary, that I must have shocked you by all the wicked
title: Dracula

text: things I've been sayin' about the dead, and such like, for weeks past;
title: Dracula

text: but I didn't mean them, and I want ye to remember that when I'm gone. We
title: Dracula

text: aud folks that be daffled, and with one foot abaft the krok-hooal, don't
title: Dracula

text: altogether like to think of it, and we don't want to feel scart of it;
title: Dracula

text: an' that's why I've took to makin' light of it, so that I'd cheer up my
title: Dracula

text: own heart a bit. But, Lord love ye, miss, I ain't afraid of dyin', not a
title: Dracula

text: bit; only I don't want to die if I can help it. My time must be nigh at
title: Dracula

text: hand now, for I be aud, and a hundred years is too much for any man to
title: Dracula

text: expect; and I'm so nigh it that the Aud Man is already whettin' his
title: Dracula

text: scythe. Ye see, I can't get out o' the habit of caffin' about it all at
title: Dracula

text: once; the chafts will wag as they be used to. Some day soon the Angel of
title: Dracula

text: Death will sound his trumpet for me. But don't ye dooal an' greet, my
title: Dracula

text: deary!"--for he saw that I was crying--"if he should come this very
title: Dracula

text: night I'd not refuse to answer his call. For life be, after all, only a
title: Dracula

text: waitin' for somethin' else than what we're doin'; and death be all that
title: Dracula

text: we can rightly depend on. But I'm content, for it's comin' to me, my
title: Dracula

text: deary, and comin' quick. It may be comin' while we be lookin' and
title: Dracula

text: wonderin'. Maybe it's in that wind out over the sea that's bringin' with
title: Dracula

text: it loss and wreck, and sore distress, and sad hearts. Look! look!" he
title: Dracula

text: cried suddenly. "There's something in that wind and in the hoast beyont
title: Dracula

text: that sounds, and looks, and tastes, and smells like death. It's in the
title: Dracula

text: air; I feel it comin'. Lord, make me answer cheerful when my call
title: Dracula

text: comes!" He held up his arms devoutly, and raised his hat. His mouth
title: Dracula

text: moved as though he were praying. After a few minutes' silence, he got
title: Dracula

text: up, shook hands with me, and blessed me, and said good-bye, and hobbled
title: Dracula

text: off. It all touched me, and upset me very much.
title: Dracula

text: I was glad when the coastguard came along, with his spy-glass under his
title: Dracula

text: arm. He stopped to talk with me, as he always does, but all the time
title: Dracula

text: kept looking at a strange ship.
title: Dracula

text: "I can't make her out," he said; "she's a Russian, by the look of her;
title: Dracula

text: but she's knocking about in the queerest way. She doesn't know her mind
title: Dracula

text: a bit; she seems to see the storm coming, but can't decide whether to
title: Dracula

text: run up north in the open, or to put in here. Look there again! She is
title: Dracula

text: steered mighty strangely, for she doesn't mind the hand on the wheel;
title: Dracula

text: changes about with every puff of wind. We'll hear more of her before
title: Dracula

text: this time to-morrow."
