text: From a Correspondent.
title: Dracula

text: _Whitby_.
title: Dracula

text: One of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been
title: Dracula

text: experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather had
title: Dracula

text: been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of
title: Dracula

text: August. Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known, and the great
title: Dracula

text: body of holiday-makers laid out yesterday for visits to Mulgrave Woods,
title: Dracula

text: Robin Hood's Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the various trips in
title: Dracula

text: the neighbourhood of Whitby. The steamers _Emma_ and _Scarborough_ made
title: Dracula

text: trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of
title: Dracula

text: "tripping" both to and from Whitby. The day was unusually fine till the
title: Dracula

text: afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff
title: Dracula

text: churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of
title: Dracula

text: sea visible to the north and east, called attention to a sudden show of
title: Dracula

text: "mares'-tails" high in the sky to the north-west. The wind was then
title: Dracula

text: blowing from the south-west in the mild degree which in barometrical
title: Dracula

text: language is ranked "No. 2: light breeze." The coastguard on duty at once
title: Dracula

text: made report, and one old fisherman, who for more than half a century has
title: Dracula

text: kept watch on weather signs from the East Cliff, foretold in an emphatic
title: Dracula

text: manner the coming of a sudden storm. The approach of sunset was so very
title: Dracula

text: beautiful, so grand in its masses of splendidly-coloured clouds, that
title: Dracula

text: there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old
title: Dracula

text: churchyard to enjoy the beauty. Before the sun dipped below the black
title: Dracula

text: mass of Kettleness, standing boldly athwart the western sky, its
title: Dracula

text: downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunset-colour--flame,
title: Dracula

text: purple, pink, green, violet, and all the tints of gold; with here and
title: Dracula

text: there masses not large, but of seemingly absolute blackness, in all
title: Dracula

text: sorts of shapes, as well outlined as colossal silhouettes. The
title: Dracula

text: experience was not lost on the painters, and doubtless some of the
title: Dracula

text: sketches of the "Prelude to the Great Storm" will grace the R. A. and R.
title: Dracula

text: I. walls in May next. More than one captain made up his mind then and
title: Dracula

text: there that his "cobble" or his "mule," as they term the different
title: Dracula

text: classes of boats, would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed.
title: Dracula

text: The wind fell away entirely during the evening, and at midnight there
title: Dracula

text: was a dead calm, a sultry heat, and that prevailing intensity which, on
title: Dracula

text: the approach of thunder, affects persons of a sensitive nature. There
title: Dracula

text: were but few lights in sight at sea, for even the coasting steamers,
title: Dracula

text: which usually "hug" the shore so closely, kept well to seaward, and but
title: Dracula

text: few fishing-boats were in sight. The only sail noticeable was a foreign
title: Dracula

text: schooner with all sails set, which was seemingly going westwards. The
title: Dracula

text: foolhardiness or ignorance of her officers was a prolific theme for
title: Dracula

text: comment whilst she remained in sight, and efforts were made to signal
title: Dracula

text: her to reduce sail in face of her danger. Before the night shut down she
title: Dracula

text: was seen with sails idly flapping as she gently rolled on the undulating
title: Dracula

text: swell of the sea,
title: Dracula

text: "As idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean."
title: Dracula

text: Shortly before ten o'clock the stillness of the air grew quite
title: Dracula

text: oppressive, and the silence was so marked that the bleating of a sheep
title: Dracula

text: inland or the barking of a dog in the town was distinctly heard, and the
title: Dracula

text: band on the pier, with its lively French air, was like a discord in the
title: Dracula

text: great harmony of nature's silence. A little after midnight came a
title: Dracula

text: strange sound from over the sea, and high overhead the air began to
title: Dracula

text: carry a strange, faint, hollow booming.
title: Dracula

text: Then without warning the tempest broke. With a rapidity which, at the
title: Dracula

text: time, seemed incredible, and even afterwards is impossible to realize,
title: Dracula

text: the whole aspect of nature at once became convulsed. The waves rose in
title: Dracula

text: growing fury, each overtopping its fellow, till in a very few minutes
title: Dracula

text: the lately glassy sea was like a roaring and devouring monster.
title: Dracula

text: White-crested waves beat madly on the level sands and rushed up the
title: Dracula

text: shelving cliffs; others broke over the piers, and with their spume swept
title: Dracula

text: the lanthorns of the lighthouses which rise from the end of either pier
title: Dracula

text: of Whitby Harbour. The wind roared like thunder, and blew with such
title: Dracula

text: force that it was with difficulty that even strong men kept their feet,
title: Dracula

text: or clung with grim clasp to the iron stanchions. It was found necessary
title: Dracula

text: to clear the entire piers from the mass of onlookers, or else the
title: Dracula

text: fatalities of the night would have been increased manifold. To add to
title: Dracula

text: the difficulties and dangers of the time, masses of sea-fog came
title: Dracula

text: drifting inland--white, wet clouds, which swept by in ghostly fashion,
title: Dracula

text: so dank and damp and cold that it needed but little effort of
title: Dracula

text: imagination to think that the spirits of those lost at sea were
title: Dracula

text: touching their living brethren with the clammy hands of death, and many
title: Dracula

text: a one shuddered as the wreaths of sea-mist swept by. At times the mist
title: Dracula

text: cleared, and the sea for some distance could be seen in the glare of the
title: Dracula

text: lightning, which now came thick and fast, followed by such sudden peals
title: Dracula

text: of thunder that the whole sky overhead seemed trembling under the shock
title: Dracula

text: of the footsteps of the storm.
title: Dracula

text: Some of the scenes thus revealed were of immeasurable grandeur and of
title: Dracula

text: absorbing interest--the sea, running mountains high, threw skywards with
title: Dracula

text: each wave mighty masses of white foam, which the tempest seemed to
title: Dracula

text: snatch at and whirl away into space; here and there a fishing-boat, with
title: Dracula

text: a rag of sail, running madly for shelter before the blast; now and again
title: Dracula

text: the white wings of a storm-tossed sea-bird. On the summit of the East
title: Dracula

text: Cliff the new searchlight was ready for experiment, but had not yet been
title: Dracula

text: tried. The officers in charge of it got it into working order, and in
title: Dracula

text: the pauses of the inrushing mist swept with it the surface of the sea.
title: Dracula

text: Once or twice its service was most effective, as when a fishing-boat,
title: Dracula

text: with gunwale under water, rushed into the harbour, able, by the guidance
title: Dracula

text: of the sheltering light, to avoid the danger of dashing against the
title: Dracula

text: piers. As each boat achieved the safety of the port there was a shout of
title: Dracula

text: joy from the mass of people on shore, a shout which for a moment seemed
title: Dracula

text: to cleave the gale and was then swept away in its rush.
title: Dracula

text: Before long the searchlight discovered some distance away a schooner
title: Dracula

text: with all sails set, apparently the same vessel which had been noticed
title: Dracula

text: earlier in the evening. The wind had by this time backed to the east,
title: Dracula

text: and there was a shudder amongst the watchers on the cliff as they
title: Dracula

text: realized the terrible danger in which she now was. Between her and the
title: Dracula

text: port lay the great flat reef on which so many good ships have from time
title: Dracula

text: to time suffered, and, with the wind blowing from its present quarter,
title: Dracula

text: it would be quite impossible that she should fetch the entrance of the
title: Dracula

text: harbour. It was now nearly the hour of high tide, but the waves were so
title: Dracula

text: great that in their troughs the shallows of the shore were almost
title: Dracula

text: visible, and the schooner, with all sails set, was rushing with such
title: Dracula

text: speed that, in the words of one old salt, "she must fetch up somewhere,
title: Dracula

text: if it was only in hell." Then came another rush of sea-fog, greater than
title: Dracula

text: any hitherto--a mass of dank mist, which seemed to close on all things
title: Dracula

text: like a grey pall, and left available to men only the organ of hearing,
title: Dracula

text: for the roar of the tempest, and the crash of the thunder, and the
title: Dracula

text: booming of the mighty billows came through the damp oblivion even louder
title: Dracula

text: than before. The rays of the searchlight were kept fixed on the harbour
title: Dracula

text: mouth across the East Pier, where the shock was expected, and men waited
title: Dracula

text: breathless. The wind suddenly shifted to the north-east, and the remnant
title: Dracula

text: of the sea-fog melted in the blast; and then, _mirabile dictu_, between
title: Dracula

text: the piers, leaping from wave to wave as it rushed at headlong speed,
title: Dracula

text: swept the strange schooner before the blast, with all sail set, and
title: Dracula

text: gained the safety of the harbour. The searchlight followed her, and a
title: Dracula

text: shudder ran through all who saw her, for lashed to the helm was a
title: Dracula

text: corpse, with drooping head, which swung horribly to and fro at each
title: Dracula

text: motion of the ship. No other form could be seen on deck at all. A great
title: Dracula

text: awe came on all as they realised that the ship, as if by a miracle, had
title: Dracula

text: found the harbour, unsteered save by the hand of a dead man! However,
title: Dracula

text: all took place more quickly than it takes to write these words. The
title: Dracula

text: schooner paused not, but rushing across the harbour, pitched herself on
title: Dracula

text: that accumulation of sand and gravel washed by many tides and many
title: Dracula

text: storms into the south-east corner of the pier jutting under the East
title: Dracula

text: Cliff, known locally as Tate Hill Pier.
title: Dracula

text: There was of course a considerable concussion as the vessel drove up on
title: Dracula

text: the sand heap. Every spar, rope, and stay was strained, and some of the
title: Dracula

text: "top-hammer" came crashing down. But, strangest of all, the very instant
title: Dracula

text: the shore was touched, an immense dog sprang up on deck from below, as
title: Dracula

text: if shot up by the concussion, and running forward, jumped from the bow
title: Dracula

text: on the sand. Making straight for the steep cliff, where the churchyard
title: Dracula

text: hangs over the laneway to the East Pier so steeply that some of the flat
title: Dracula

text: tombstones--"thruff-steans" or "through-stones," as they call them in
title: Dracula

text: the Whitby vernacular--actually project over where the sustaining cliff
title: Dracula

text: has fallen away, it disappeared in the darkness, which seemed
title: Dracula

text: intensified just beyond the focus of the searchlight.
title: Dracula

text: It so happened that there was no one at the moment on Tate Hill Pier, as
title: Dracula

text: all those whose houses are in close proximity were either in bed or were
title: Dracula

text: out on the heights above. Thus the coastguard on duty on the eastern
title: Dracula

text: side of the harbour, who at once ran down to the little pier, was the
title: Dracula

text: first to climb on board. The men working the searchlight, after scouring
title: Dracula

text: the entrance of the harbour without seeing anything, then turned the
title: Dracula

text: light on the derelict and kept it there. The coastguard ran aft, and
title: Dracula

text: when he came beside the wheel, bent over to examine it, and recoiled at
title: Dracula

text: once as though under some sudden emotion. This seemed to pique general
title: Dracula

text: curiosity, and quite a number of people began to run. It is a good way
title: Dracula

text: round from the West Cliff by the Drawbridge to Tate Hill Pier, but your
title: Dracula

text: correspondent is a fairly good runner, and came well ahead of the crowd.
title: Dracula

text: When I arrived, however, I found already assembled on the pier a crowd,
title: Dracula

text: whom the coastguard and police refused to allow to come on board. By the
title: Dracula

text: courtesy of the chief boatman, I was, as your correspondent, permitted
title: Dracula

text: to climb on deck, and was one of a small group who saw the dead seaman
title: Dracula

text: whilst actually lashed to the wheel.
title: Dracula

text: It was no wonder that the coastguard was surprised, or even awed, for
title: Dracula

text: not often can such a sight have been seen. The man was simply fastened
title: Dracula

text: by his hands, tied one over the other, to a spoke of the wheel. Between
title: Dracula

text: the inner hand and the wood was a crucifix, the set of beads on which it
title: Dracula

text: was fastened being around both wrists and wheel, and all kept fast by
title: Dracula

text: the binding cords. The poor fellow may have been seated at one time, but
title: Dracula

text: the flapping and buffeting of the sails had worked through the rudder of
title: Dracula

text: the wheel and dragged him to and fro, so that the cords with which he
title: Dracula

text: was tied had cut the flesh to the bone. Accurate note was made of the
title: Dracula

text: state of things, and a doctor--Surgeon J. M. Caffyn, of 33, East Elliot
title: Dracula

text: Place--who came immediately after me, declared, after making
title: Dracula

text: examination, that the man must have been dead for quite two days. In his
title: Dracula

text: pocket was a bottle, carefully corked, empty save for a little roll of
title: Dracula

text: paper, which proved to be the addendum to the log. The coastguard said
title: Dracula

text: the man must have tied up his own hands, fastening the knots with his
title: Dracula

text: teeth. The fact that a coastguard was the first on board may save some
title: Dracula

text: complications, later on, in the Admiralty Court; for coastguards cannot
title: Dracula

text: claim the salvage which is the right of the first civilian entering on a
title: Dracula

text: derelict. Already, however, the legal tongues are wagging, and one young
title: Dracula

text: law student is loudly asserting that the rights of the owner are already
title: Dracula

text: completely sacrificed, his property being held in contravention of the
title: Dracula

text: statutes of mortmain, since the tiller, as emblemship, if not proof, of
title: Dracula

text: delegated possession, is held in a _dead hand_. It is needless to say
title: Dracula

text: that the dead steersman has been reverently removed from the place where
title: Dracula

text: he held his honourable watch and ward till death--a steadfastness as
title: Dracula

text: noble as that of the young Casabianca--and placed in the mortuary to
title: Dracula

text: await inquest.
title: Dracula

text: Already the sudden storm is passing, and its fierceness is abating;
title: Dracula

text: crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over
title: Dracula

text: the Yorkshire wolds. I shall send, in time for your next issue, further
title: Dracula

text: details of the derelict ship which found her way so miraculously into
title: Dracula

text: harbour in the storm.

title: Dracula

text: _9 August._--The sequel to the strange arrival of the derelict in the
title: Dracula

text: storm last night is almost more startling than the thing itself. It
title: Dracula

text: turns out that the schooner is a Russian from Varna, and is called the
title: Dracula

text: _Demeter_. She is almost entirely in ballast of silver sand, with only a
title: Dracula

text: small amount of cargo--a number of great wooden boxes filled with mould.
title: Dracula

text: This cargo was consigned to a Whitby solicitor, Mr. S. F. Billington, of
title: Dracula

text: 7, The Crescent, who this morning went aboard and formally took
title: Dracula

text: possession of the goods consigned to him. The Russian consul, too,
title: Dracula

text: acting for the charter-party, took formal possession of the ship, and
title: Dracula

text: paid all harbour dues, etc. Nothing is talked about here to-day except
title: Dracula

text: the strange coincidence; the officials of the Board of Trade have been
title: Dracula

text: most exacting in seeing that every compliance has been made with
title: Dracula

text: existing regulations. As the matter is to be a "nine days' wonder," they
title: Dracula

text: are evidently determined that there shall be no cause of after
title: Dracula

text: complaint. A good deal of interest was abroad concerning the dog which
title: Dracula

text: landed when the ship struck, and more than a few of the members of the
title: Dracula

text: S. P. C. A., which is very strong in Whitby, have tried to befriend the
title: Dracula

text: animal. To the general disappointment, however, it was not to be found;
title: Dracula

text: it seems to have disappeared entirely from the town. It may be that it
title: Dracula

text: was frightened and made its way on to the moors, where it is still
title: Dracula

text: hiding in terror. There are some who look with dread on such a
title: Dracula

text: possibility, lest later on it should in itself become a danger, for it
title: Dracula

text: is evidently a fierce brute. Early this morning a large dog, a half-bred
title: Dracula

text: mastiff belonging to a coal merchant close to Tate Hill Pier, was found
title: Dracula

text: dead in the roadway opposite to its master's yard. It had been fighting,
title: Dracula

text: and manifestly had had a savage opponent, for its throat was torn away,
title: Dracula

text: and its belly was slit open as if with a savage claw.
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--By the kindness of the Board of Trade inspector, I have been
title: Dracula

text: permitted to look over the log-book of the _Demeter_, which was in order
title: Dracula

text: up to within three days, but contained nothing of special interest
title: Dracula

text: except as to facts of missing men. The greatest interest, however, is
title: Dracula

text: with regard to the paper found in the bottle, which was to-day produced
title: Dracula

text: at the inquest; and a more strange narrative than the two between them
title: Dracula

text: unfold it has not been my lot to come across. As there is no motive for
title: Dracula

text: concealment, I am permitted to use them, and accordingly send you a
title: Dracula

text: rescript, simply omitting technical details of seamanship and
title: Dracula

text: supercargo. It almost seems as though the captain had been seized with
title: Dracula

text: some kind of mania before he had got well into blue water, and that
title: Dracula

text: this had developed persistently throughout the voyage. Of course my
title: Dracula

text: statement must be taken _cum grano_, since I am writing from the
title: Dracula

text: dictation of a clerk of the Russian consul, who kindly translated for
title: Dracula

text: me, time being short.
title: Dracula

text: LOG OF THE "DEMETER."
title: Dracula

text: _Varna to Whitby._
title: Dracula

text: _Written 18 July, things so strange happening, that I shall keep
title: Dracula

text: accurate note henceforth till we land._
title: Dracula

text: On 6 July we finished taking in cargo, silver sand and boxes of earth.
title: Dracula

text: At noon set sail. East wind, fresh. Crew, five hands ... two mates,
title: Dracula

text: cook, and myself (captain).
title: Dracula

text: On 11 July at dawn entered Bosphorus. Boarded by Turkish Customs
title: Dracula

text: officers. Backsheesh. All correct. Under way at 4 p. m.
title: Dracula

text: On 12 July through Dardanelles. More Customs officers and flagboat of
title: Dracula

text: guarding squadron. Backsheesh again. Work of officers thorough, but
title: Dracula

text: quick. Want us off soon. At dark passed into Archipelago.
title: Dracula

text: On 13 July passed Cape Matapan. Crew dissatisfied about something.
title: Dracula

text: Seemed scared, but would not speak out.
title: Dracula

text: On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew. Men all steady fellows, who
title: Dracula

text: sailed with me before. Mate could not make out what was wrong; they only
title: Dracula

text: told him there was _something_, and crossed themselves. Mate lost temper
title: Dracula

text: with one of them that day and struck him. Expected fierce quarrel, but
title: Dracula

text: all was quiet.
title: Dracula

text: On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, Petrofsky, was
title: Dracula

text: missing. Could not account for it. Took larboard watch eight bells last
title: Dracula

text: night; was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk. Men more
title: Dracula

text: downcast than ever. All said they expected something of the kind, but
title: Dracula

text: would not say more than there was _something_ aboard. Mate getting very
title: Dracula

text: impatient with them; feared some trouble ahead.
title: Dracula

text: On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in
title: Dracula

text: an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man
title: Dracula

text: aboard the ship. He said that in his watch he had been sheltering
title: Dracula

text: behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall,
title: Dracula

text: thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way,
title: Dracula

text: and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously,
title: Dracula

text: but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed.
title: Dracula

text: He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may
title: Dracula

text: spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from
title: Dracula

text: stem to stern.
title: Dracula

text: Later in the day I got together the whole crew, and told them, as they
title: Dracula

text: evidently thought there was some one in the ship, we would search from
title: Dracula

text: stem to stern. First mate angry; said it was folly, and to yield to such
title: Dracula

text: foolish ideas would demoralise the men; said he would engage to keep
title: Dracula

text: them out of trouble with a handspike. I let him take the helm, while the
title: Dracula

text: rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: we left
title: Dracula

text: no corner unsearched. As there were only the big wooden boxes, there
title: Dracula

text: were no odd corners where a man could hide. Men much relieved when
title: Dracula

text: search over, and went back to work cheerfully. First mate scowled, but
title: Dracula

text: said nothing.
title: Dracula

text: _22 July_.--Rough weather last three days, and all hands busy with
title: Dracula

text: sails--no time to be frightened. Men seem to have forgotten their dread.
title: Dracula

text: Mate cheerful again, and all on good terms. Praised men for work in bad
title: Dracula

text: weather. Passed Gibralter and out through Straits. All well.
title: Dracula

text: _24 July_.--There seems some doom over this ship. Already a hand short,
title: Dracula

text: and entering on the Bay of Biscay with wild weather ahead, and yet last
title: Dracula

text: night another man lost--disappeared. Like the first, he came off his
title: Dracula

text: watch and was not seen again. Men all in a panic of fear; sent a round
title: Dracula

text: robin, asking to have double watch, as they fear to be alone. Mate
title: Dracula

text: angry. Fear there will be some trouble, as either he or the men will do
title: Dracula

text: some violence.
title: Dracula

text: _28 July_.--Four days in hell, knocking about in a sort of maelstrom,
title: Dracula

text: and the wind a tempest. No sleep for any one. Men all worn out. Hardly
title: Dracula

text: know how to set a watch, since no one fit to go on. Second mate
title: Dracula

text: volunteered to steer and watch, and let men snatch a few hours' sleep.
title: Dracula

text: Wind abating; seas still terrific, but feel them less, as ship is
title: Dracula

text: steadier.
title: Dracula

text: _29 July_.--Another tragedy. Had single watch to-night, as crew too
title: Dracula

text: tired to double. When morning watch came on deck could find no one
title: Dracula

text: except steersman. Raised outcry, and all came on deck. Thorough search,
title: Dracula

text: but no one found. Are now without second mate, and crew in a panic. Mate
title: Dracula

text: and I agreed to go armed henceforth and wait for any sign of cause.
title: Dracula

text: _30 July_.--Last night. Rejoiced we are nearing England. Weather fine,
title: Dracula

text: all sails set. Retired worn out; slept soundly; awaked by mate telling
title: Dracula

text: me that both man of watch and steersman missing. Only self and mate and
title: Dracula

text: two hands left to work ship.
title: Dracula

text: _1 August_.--Two days of fog, and not a sail sighted. Had hoped when in
title: Dracula

text: the English Channel to be able to signal for help or get in somewhere.
title: Dracula

text: Not having power to work sails, have to run before wind. Dare not lower,
title: Dracula

text: as could not raise them again. We seem to be drifting to some terrible
title: Dracula

text: doom. Mate now more demoralised than either of men. His stronger nature
title: Dracula

text: seems to have worked inwardly against himself. Men are beyond fear,
title: Dracula

text: working stolidly and patiently, with minds made up to worst. They are
title: Dracula

text: Russian, he Roumanian.
title: Dracula

text: _2 August, midnight_.--Woke up from few minutes' sleep by hearing a cry,
title: Dracula

text: seemingly outside my port. Could see nothing in fog. Rushed on deck, and
title: Dracula

text: ran against mate. Tells me heard cry and ran, but no sign of man on
title: Dracula

text: watch. One more gone. Lord, help us! Mate says we must be past Straits
title: Dracula

text: of Dover, as in a moment of fog lifting he saw North Foreland, just as
title: Dracula

text: he heard the man cry out. If so we are now off in the North Sea, and
title: Dracula

text: only God can guide us in the fog, which seems to move with us; and God
title: Dracula

text: seems to have deserted us.
title: Dracula

text: _3 August_.--At midnight I went to relieve the man at the wheel, and
title: Dracula

text: when I got to it found no one there. The wind was steady, and as we ran
title: Dracula

text: before it there was no yawing. I dared not leave it, so shouted for the
title: Dracula

text: mate. After a few seconds he rushed up on deck in his flannels. He
title: Dracula

text: looked wild-eyed and haggard, and I greatly fear his reason has given
title: Dracula

text: way. He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, with his mouth to my
title: Dracula

text: ear, as though fearing the very air might hear: "_It_ is here; I know
title: Dracula

text: it, now. On the watch last night I saw It, like a man, tall and thin,
title: Dracula

text: and ghastly pale. It was in the bows, and looking out. I crept behind
title: Dracula

text: It, and gave It my knife; but the knife went through It, empty as the
title: Dracula

text: air." And as he spoke he took his knife and drove it savagely into
title: Dracula

text: space. Then he went on: "But It is here, and I'll find It. It is in the
title: Dracula

text: hold, perhaps in one of those boxes. I'll unscrew them one by one and
title: Dracula

text: see. You work the helm." And, with a warning look and his finger on his
title: Dracula

text: lip, he went below. There was springing up a choppy wind, and I could
title: Dracula

text: not leave the helm. I saw him come out on deck again with a tool-chest
title: Dracula

text: and a lantern, and go down the forward hatchway. He is mad, stark,
title: Dracula

text: raving mad, and it's no use my trying to stop him. He can't hurt those
title: Dracula

text: big boxes: they are invoiced as "clay," and to pull them about is as
title: Dracula

text: harmless a thing as he can do. So here I stay, and mind the helm, and
title: Dracula

text: write these notes. I can only trust in God and wait till the fog clears.
title: Dracula

text: Then, if I can't steer to any harbour with the wind that is, I shall cut
title: Dracula

text: down sails and lie by, and signal for help....
title: Dracula

text: It is nearly all over now. Just as I was beginning to hope that the mate
title: Dracula

text: would come out calmer--for I heard him knocking away at something in the
title: Dracula

text: hold, and work is good for him--there came up the hatchway a sudden,
title: Dracula

text: startled scream, which made my blood run cold, and up on the deck he
title: Dracula

text: came as if shot from a gun--a raging madman, with his eyes rolling and
title: Dracula

text: his face convulsed with fear. "Save me! save me!" he cried, and then
title: Dracula

text: looked round on the blanket of fog. His horror turned to despair, and in
title: Dracula

text: a steady voice he said: "You had better come too, captain, before it is
title: Dracula

text: too late. _He_ is there. I know the secret now. The sea will save me
title: Dracula

text: from Him, and it is all that is left!" Before I could say a word, or
title: Dracula

text: move forward to seize him, he sprang on the bulwark and deliberately
title: Dracula

text: threw himself into the sea. I suppose I know the secret too, now. It was
title: Dracula

text: this madman who had got rid of the men one by one, and now he has
title: Dracula

text: followed them himself. God help me! How am I to account for all these
title: Dracula

text: horrors when I get to port? _When_ I get to port! Will that ever be?
title: Dracula

text: _4 August._--Still fog, which the sunrise cannot pierce. I know there is
title: Dracula

text: sunrise because I am a sailor, why else I know not. I dared not go
title: Dracula

text: below, I dared not leave the helm; so here all night I stayed, and in
title: Dracula

text: the dimness of the night I saw It--Him! God forgive me, but the mate was
title: Dracula

text: right to jump overboard. It was better to die like a man; to die like a
title: Dracula

text: sailor in blue water no man can object. But I am captain, and I must not
title: Dracula

text: leave my ship. But I shall baffle this fiend or monster, for I shall tie
title: Dracula

text: my hands to the wheel when my strength begins to fail, and along with
title: Dracula

text: them I shall tie that which He--It!--dare not touch; and then, come good
title: Dracula

text: wind or foul, I shall save my soul, and my honour as a captain. I am
title: Dracula

text: growing weaker, and the night is coming on. If He can look me in the
title: Dracula

text: face again, I may not have time to act.... If we are wrecked, mayhap
title: Dracula

text: this bottle may be found, and those who find it may understand; if not,
title: Dracula

text: ... well, then all men shall know that I have been true to my trust. God
title: Dracula

text: and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying
title: Dracula

text: to do his duty....
title: Dracula

text: Of course the verdict was an open one. There is no evidence to adduce;
title: Dracula

text: and whether or not the man himself committed the murders there is now
title: Dracula

text: none to say. The folk here hold almost universally that the captain is
title: Dracula

text: simply a hero, and he is to be given a public funeral. Already it is
title: Dracula

text: arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats up the Esk
title: Dracula

text: for a piece and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and up the abbey
title: Dracula

text: steps; for he is to be buried in the churchyard on the cliff. The owners
title: Dracula

text: of more than a hundred boats have already given in their names as
title: Dracula

text: wishing to follow him to the grave.
title: Dracula

text: No trace has ever been found of the great dog; at which there is much
title: Dracula

text: mourning, for, with public opinion in its present state, he would, I
title: Dracula

text: believe, be adopted by the town. To-morrow will see the funeral; and so
title: Dracula

text: will end this one more "mystery of the sea."
title: Dracula

text: _Mina Murray's Journal._
title: Dracula

text: _8 August._--Lucy was very restless all night, and I, too, could not
title: Dracula

text: sleep. The storm was fearful, and as it boomed loudly among the
title: Dracula

text: chimney-pots, it made me shudder. When a sharp puff came it seemed to be
title: Dracula

text: like a distant gun. Strangely enough, Lucy did not wake; but she got up
title: Dracula

text: twice and dressed herself. Fortunately, each time I awoke in time and
title: Dracula

text: managed to undress her without waking her, and got her back to bed. It
title: Dracula

text: is a very strange thing, this sleep-walking, for as soon as her will is
title: Dracula

text: thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if there be any,
title: Dracula

text: disappears, and she yields herself almost exactly to the routine of her
title: Dracula

text: life.
title: Dracula

text: Early in the morning we both got up and went down to the harbour to see
title: Dracula

text: if anything had happened in the night. There were very few people about,
title: Dracula

text: and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big,
title: Dracula

text: grim-looking waves, that seemed dark themselves because the foam that
title: Dracula

text: topped them was like snow, forced themselves in through the narrow mouth
title: Dracula

text: of the harbour--like a bullying man going through a crowd. Somehow I
title: Dracula

text: felt glad that Jonathan was not on the sea last night, but on land. But,
title: Dracula

text: oh, is he on land or sea? Where is he, and how? I am getting fearfully
title: Dracula

text: anxious about him. If I only knew what to do, and could do anything!
title: Dracula

text: _10 August._--The funeral of the poor sea-captain to-day was most
title: Dracula

text: touching. Every boat in the harbour seemed to be there, and the coffin
title: Dracula

text: was carried by captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier up to the
title: Dracula

text: churchyard. Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old seat, whilst
title: Dracula

text: the cortège of boats went up the river to the Viaduct and came down
title: Dracula

text: again. We had a lovely view, and saw the procession nearly all the way.
title: Dracula

text: The poor fellow was laid to rest quite near our seat so that we stood on
title: Dracula

text: it when the time came and saw everything. Poor Lucy seemed much upset.
title: Dracula

text: She was restless and uneasy all the time, and I cannot but think that
title: Dracula

text: her dreaming at night is telling on her. She is quite odd in one thing:
title: Dracula

text: she will not admit to me that there is any cause for restlessness; or if
title: Dracula

text: there be, she does not understand it herself. There is an additional
title: Dracula

text: cause in that poor old Mr. Swales was found dead this morning on our
title: Dracula

text: seat, his neck being broken. He had evidently, as the doctor said,
title: Dracula

text: fallen back in the seat in some sort of fright, for there was a look of
title: Dracula

text: fear and horror on his face that the men said made them shudder. Poor
title: Dracula

text: dear old man! Perhaps he had seen Death with his dying eyes! Lucy is so
title: Dracula

text: sweet and sensitive that she feels influences more acutely than other
title: Dracula

text: people do. Just now she was quite upset by a little thing which I did
title: Dracula

text: not much heed, though I am myself very fond of animals. One of the men
title: Dracula

text: who came up here often to look for the boats was followed by his dog.
title: Dracula

text: The dog is always with him. They are both quiet persons, and I never saw
title: Dracula

text: the man angry, nor heard the dog bark. During the service the dog would
title: Dracula

text: not come to its master, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few
title: Dracula

text: yards off, barking and howling. Its master spoke to it gently, and then
title: Dracula

text: harshly, and then angrily; but it would neither come nor cease to make a
title: Dracula

text: noise. It was in a sort of fury, with its eyes savage, and all its hairs
title: Dracula

text: bristling out like a cat's tail when puss is on the war-path. Finally
title: Dracula

text: the man, too, got angry, and jumped down and kicked the dog, and then
title: Dracula

text: took it by the scruff of the neck and half dragged and half threw it on
title: Dracula

text: the tombstone on which the seat is fixed. The moment it touched the
title: Dracula

text: stone the poor thing became quiet and fell all into a tremble. It did
title: Dracula

text: not try to get away, but crouched down, quivering and cowering, and was
title: Dracula

text: in such a pitiable state of terror that I tried, though without effect,
title: Dracula

text: to comfort it. Lucy was full of pity, too, but she did not attempt to
title: Dracula

text: touch the dog, but looked at it in an agonised sort of way. I greatly
title: Dracula

text: fear that she is of too super-sensitive a nature to go through the world
title: Dracula

text: without trouble. She will be dreaming of this to-night, I am sure. The
title: Dracula

text: whole agglomeration of things--the ship steered into port by a dead
title: Dracula

text: man; his attitude, tied to the wheel with a crucifix and beads; the
title: Dracula

text: touching funeral; the dog, now furious and now in terror--will all
title: Dracula

text: afford material for her dreams.
title: Dracula

text: I think it will be best for her to go to bed tired out physically, so I
title: Dracula

text: shall take her for a long walk by the cliffs to Robin Hood's Bay and
title: Dracula

text: back. She ought not to have much inclination for sleep-walking then.
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Dracula

text: MINA MURRAY'S JOURNAL
title: Dracula

text: _Same day, 11 o'clock p. m._--Oh, but I am tired! If it were not that I
title: Dracula

text: had made my diary a duty I should not open it to-night. We had a lovely
title: Dracula

text: walk. Lucy, after a while, was in gay spirits, owing, I think, to some
title: Dracula

text: dear cows who came nosing towards us in a field close to the lighthouse,
title: Dracula

text: and frightened the wits out of us. I believe we forgot everything
title: Dracula

text: except, of course, personal fear, and it seemed to wipe the slate clean
title: Dracula

text: and give us a fresh start. We had a capital "severe tea" at Robin Hood's
title: Dracula

text: Bay in a sweet little old-fashioned inn, with a bow-window right over
title: Dracula

text: the seaweed-covered rocks of the strand. I believe we should have
title: Dracula

text: shocked the "New Woman" with our appetites. Men are more tolerant, bless
title: Dracula

text: them! Then we walked home with some, or rather many, stoppages to rest,
title: Dracula

text: and with our hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls. Lucy was
title: Dracula

text: really tired, and we intended to creep off to bed as soon as we could.
title: Dracula

text: The young curate came in, however, and Mrs. Westenra asked him to stay
title: Dracula

text: for supper. Lucy and I had both a fight for it with the dusty miller; I
title: Dracula

text: know it was a hard fight on my part, and I am quite heroic. I think that
title: Dracula

text: some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new
title: Dracula

text: class of curates, who don't take supper, no matter how they may be
title: Dracula

text: pressed to, and who will know when girls are tired. Lucy is asleep and
title: Dracula

text: breathing softly. She has more colour in her cheeks than usual, and
title: Dracula

text: looks, oh, so sweet. If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her seeing her
title: Dracula

text: only in the drawing-room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now.
title: Dracula

text: Some of the "New Women" writers will some day start an idea that men and
title: Dracula

text: women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or
title: Dracula

text: accepting. But I suppose the New Woman won't condescend in future to
title: Dracula

text: accept; she will do the proposing herself. And a nice job she will make
title: Dracula

text: of it, too! There's some consolation in that. I am so happy to-night,
title: Dracula

text: because dear Lucy seems better. I really believe she has turned the
title: Dracula

text: corner, and that we are over her troubles with dreaming. I should be
title: Dracula

text: quite happy if I only knew if Jonathan.... God bless and keep him.
title: Dracula

text: _11 August, 3 a. m._--Diary again. No sleep now, so I may as well write.
title: Dracula

text: I am too agitated to sleep. We have had such an adventure, such an
title: Dracula

text: agonising experience. I fell asleep as soon as I had closed my diary....
title: Dracula

text: Suddenly I became broad awake, and sat up, with a horrible sense of fear
title: Dracula

text: upon me, and of some feeling of emptiness around me. The room was dark,
title: Dracula

text: so I could not see Lucy's bed; I stole across and felt for her. The bed
title: Dracula

text: was empty. I lit a match and found that she was not in the room. The
title: Dracula

text: door was shut, but not locked, as I had left it. I feared to wake her
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: thing about.

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: not to have even changed her side. The adventure of the night does not
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: was wakened by Lucy trying to get out. She seemed, even in her sleep, to
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: to have become as much in love with the spot as I am, and it is hard to

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _18 August._--I am happy to-day, and write sitting on the seat in the
title: Dracula

text: churchyard. Lucy is ever so much better. Last night she slept well all
title: Dracula

text: night, and did not disturb me once. The roses seem coming back already
title: Dracula

text: to her cheeks, though she is still sadly pale and wan-looking. If she
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "I didn't quite dream; but it all seemed to be real. I only wanted to be

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: through the streets and over the bridge. A fish leaped as I went by, and
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: survive this night. God keep you, dear, and God help me!
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER XII
title: Dracula

text: DR. SEWARD'S DIARY
title: Dracula

text: _18 September._--I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early.
title: Dracula

text: Keeping my cab at the gate, I went up the avenue alone. I knocked gently
title: Dracula

text: and rang as quietly as possible, for I feared to disturb Lucy or her
title: Dracula

text: mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door. After a while,
title: Dracula

text: finding no response, I knocked and rang again; still no answer. I cursed
title: Dracula

text: the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an
title: Dracula

text: hour--for it was now ten o'clock--and so rang and knocked again, but
title: Dracula

text: more impatiently, but still without response. Hitherto I had blamed only
title: Dracula

text: the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this
title: Dracula

text: desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing
title: Dracula

text: tight around us? Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come, too
title: Dracula

text: late? I knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of
title: Dracula

text: danger to Lucy, if she had had again one of those frightful relapses;
title: Dracula

text: and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry
title: Dracula

text: anywhere.
title: Dracula

text: I could find no means of ingress. Every window and door was fastened and
title: Dracula

text: locked, and I returned baffled to the porch. As I did so, I heard the
title: Dracula

text: rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse's feet. They stopped at the
title: Dracula

text: gate, and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue.
title: Dracula

text: When he saw me, he gasped out:--
title: Dracula

text: "Then it was you, and just arrived. How is she? Are we too late? Did you
title: Dracula

text: not get my telegram?"
title: Dracula

text: I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his
title: Dracula

text: telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here,
title: Dracula

text: and that I could not make any one in the house hear me. He paused and
title: Dracula

text: raised his hat as he said solemnly:--
title: Dracula

text: "Then I fear we are too late. God's will be done!" With his usual
title: Dracula

text: recuperative energy, he went on: "Come. If there be no way open to get
title: Dracula

text: in, we must make one. Time is all in all to us now."
title: Dracula

text: We went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen
title: Dracula

text: window. The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case, and
title: Dracula

text: handing it to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window. I
title: Dracula

text: attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them. Then
title: Dracula

text: with a long, thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and
title: Dracula

text: opened the window. I helped the Professor in, and followed him. There
title: Dracula

text: was no one in the kitchen or in the servants' rooms, which were close at
title: Dracula

text: hand. We tried all the rooms as we went along, and in the dining-room,
title: Dracula

text: dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four
title: Dracula

text: servant-women lying on the floor. There was no need to think them dead,
title: Dracula

text: for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the
title: Dracula

text: room left no doubt as to their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at
title: Dracula

text: each other, and as we moved away he said: "We can attend to them later."
title: Dracula

text: Then we ascended to Lucy's room. For an instant or two we paused at the
title: Dracula

text: door to listen, but there was no sound that we could hear. With white
title: Dracula

text: faces and trembling hands, we opened the door gently, and entered the
title: Dracula

text: room.
title: Dracula

text: How shall I describe what we saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her
title: Dracula

text: mother. The latter lay farthest in, and she was covered with a white
title: Dracula

text: sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the
title: Dracula

text: broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror
title: Dracula

text: fixed upon it. By her side lay Lucy, with face white and still more
title: Dracula

text: drawn. The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her
title: Dracula

text: mother's bosom, and her throat was bare, showing the two little wounds
title: Dracula

text: which we had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled.
title: Dracula

text: Without a word the Professor bent over the bed, his head almost touching
title: Dracula

text: poor Lucy's breast; then he gave a quick turn of his head, as of one who
title: Dracula

text: listens, and leaping to his feet, he cried out to me:--
title: Dracula

text: "It is not yet too late! Quick! quick! Bring the brandy!"
title: Dracula

text: I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste
title: Dracula

text: it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found
title: Dracula

text: on the table. The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and I
title: Dracula

text: fancied that the narcotic was wearing off. I did not stay to make sure,
title: Dracula

text: but returned to Van Helsing. He rubbed the brandy, as on another
title: Dracula

text: occasion, on her lips and gums and on her wrists and the palms of her
title: Dracula

text: hands. He said to me:--
title: Dracula

text: "I can do this, all that can be at the present. You go wake those maids.
title: Dracula

text: Flick them in the face with a wet towel, and flick them hard. Make them
title: Dracula

text: get heat and fire and a warm bath. This poor soul is nearly as cold as
title: Dracula

text: that beside her. She will need be heated before we can do anything
title: Dracula

text: more."
title: Dracula

text: I went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the
title: Dracula

text: women. The fourth was only a young girl, and the drug had evidently
title: Dracula

text: affected her more strongly, so I lifted her on the sofa and let her
title: Dracula

text: sleep. The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to
title: Dracula

text: them they cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner. I was stern with
title: Dracula

text: them, however, and would not let them talk. I told them that one life
title: Dracula

text: was bad enough to lose, and that if they delayed they would sacrifice
title: Dracula

text: Miss Lucy. So, sobbing and crying, they went about their way, half clad
title: Dracula

text: as they were, and prepared fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and
title: Dracula

text: boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water. We
title: Dracula

text: got a bath and carried Lucy out as she was and placed her in it. Whilst
title: Dracula

text: we were busy chafing her limbs there was a knock at the hall door. One
title: Dracula

text: of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it. Then
title: Dracula

text: she returned and whispered to us that there was a gentleman who had come
title: Dracula

text: with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I bade her simply tell him that he
title: Dracula

text: must wait, for we could see no one now. She went away with the message,
title: Dracula

text: and, engrossed with our work, I clean forgot all about him.
title: Dracula

text: I never saw in all my experience the Professor work in such deadly
title: Dracula

text: earnest. I knew--as he knew--that it was a stand-up fight with death,
title: Dracula

text: and in a pause told him so. He answered me in a way that I did not
title: Dracula

text: understand, but with the sternest look that his face could wear:--
title: Dracula

text: "If that were all, I would stop here where we are now, and let her fade
title: Dracula

text: away into peace, for I see no light in life over her horizon." He went
title: Dracula

text: on with his work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour.
title: Dracula

text: Presently we both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to
title: Dracula

text: be of some effect. Lucy's heart beat a trifle more audibly to the
title: Dracula

text: stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement. Van Helsing's
title: Dracula

text: face almost beamed, and as we lifted her from the bath and rolled her in
title: Dracula

text: a hot sheet to dry her he said to me:--
title: Dracula

text: "The first gain is ours! Check to the King!"
title: Dracula

text: We took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid
title: Dracula

text: her in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down her throat. I noticed
title: Dracula

text: that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief round her throat. She was
title: Dracula

text: still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, we had
title: Dracula

text: ever seen her.
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing called in one of the women, and told her to stay with her
title: Dracula

text: and not to take her eyes off her till we returned, and then beckoned me
title: Dracula

text: out of the room.
title: Dracula

text: "We must consult as to what is to be done," he said as we descended the
title: Dracula

text: stairs. In the hall he opened the dining-room door, and we passed in, he
title: Dracula

text: closing the door carefully behind him. The shutters had been opened, but
title: Dracula

text: the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of
title: Dracula

text: death which the British woman of the lower classes always rigidly
title: Dracula

text: observes. The room was, therefore, dimly dark. It was, however, light
title: Dracula

text: enough for our purposes. Van Helsing's sternness was somewhat relieved
title: Dracula

text: by a look of perplexity. He was evidently torturing his mind about
title: Dracula

text: something, so I waited for an instant, and he spoke:--
title: Dracula

text: "What are we to do now? Where are we to turn for help? We must have
title: Dracula

text: another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl's life
title: Dracula

text: won't be worth an hour's purchase. You are exhausted already; I am
title: Dracula

text: exhausted too. I fear to trust those women, even if they would have
title: Dracula

text: courage to submit. What are we to do for some one who will open his
title: Dracula

text: veins for her?"
title: Dracula

text: "What's the matter with me, anyhow?"
title: Dracula

text: The voice came from the sofa across the room, and its tones brought
title: Dracula

text: relief and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris. Van
title: Dracula

text: Helsing started angrily at the first sound, but his face softened and a
title: Dracula

text: glad look came into his eyes as I cried out: "Quincey Morris!" and
title: Dracula

text: rushed towards him with outstretched hands.
title: Dracula

text: "What brought you here?" I cried as our hands met.
title: Dracula

text: "I guess Art is the cause."
title: Dracula

text: He handed me a telegram:--
title: Dracula

text: "Have not heard from Seward for three days, and am terribly anxious.
title: Dracula

text: Cannot leave. Father still in same condition. Send me word how Lucy is.
title: Dracula

text: Do not delay.--HOLMWOOD."
title: Dracula

text: "I think I came just in the nick of time. You know you have only to tell
title: Dracula

text: me what to do."
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing strode forward, and took his hand, looking him straight in
title: Dracula

text: the eyes as he said:--
title: Dracula

text: "A brave man's blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in
title: Dracula

text: trouble. You're a man and no mistake. Well, the devil may work against
title: Dracula

text: us for all he's worth, but God sends us men when we want them."
title: Dracula

text: Once again we went through that ghastly operation. I have not the heart
title: Dracula

text: to go through with the details. Lucy had got a terrible shock and it
title: Dracula

text: told on her more than before, for though plenty of blood went into her
title: Dracula

text: veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as well as on the other
title: Dracula

text: occasions. Her struggle back into life was something frightful to see
title: Dracula

text: and hear. However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and Van
title: Dracula

text: Helsing made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with
title: Dracula

text: good effect. Her faint became a profound slumber. The Professor watched
title: Dracula

text: whilst I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and sent one of the maids
title: Dracula

text: to pay off one of the cabmen who were waiting. I left Quincey lying down
title: Dracula

text: after having a glass of wine, and told the cook to get ready a good
title: Dracula

text: breakfast. Then a thought struck me, and I went back to the room where
title: Dracula

text: Lucy now was. When I came softly in, I found Van Helsing with a sheet or
title: Dracula

text: two of note-paper in his hand. He had evidently read it, and was
title: Dracula

text: thinking it over as he sat with his hand to his brow. There was a look
title: Dracula

text: of grim satisfaction in his face, as of one who has had a doubt solved.
title: Dracula

text: He handed me the paper saying only: "It dropped from Lucy's breast when
title: Dracula

text: we carried her to the bath."
title: Dracula

text: When I had read it, I stood looking at the Professor, and after a pause
title: Dracula

text: asked him: "In God's name, what does it all mean? Was she, or is she,
title: Dracula

text: mad; or what sort of horrible danger is it?" I was so bewildered that I
title: Dracula

text: did not know what to say more. Van Helsing put out his hand and took the
title: Dracula

text: paper, saying:--
title: Dracula

text: "Do not trouble about it now. Forget it for the present. You shall know
title: Dracula

text: and understand it all in good time; but it will be later. And now what
title: Dracula

text: is it that you came to me to say?" This brought me back to fact, and I
title: Dracula

text: was all myself again.
title: Dracula

text: "I came to speak about the certificate of death. If we do not act
title: Dracula

text: properly and wisely, there may be an inquest, and that paper would have
title: Dracula

text: to be produced. I am in hopes that we need have no inquest, for if we
title: Dracula

text: had it would surely kill poor Lucy, if nothing else did. I know, and you
title: Dracula

text: know, and the other doctor who attended her knows, that Mrs. Westenra
title: Dracula

text: had disease of the heart, and we can certify that she died of it. Let us
title: Dracula

text: fill up the certificate at once, and I shall take it myself to the
title: Dracula

text: registrar and go on to the undertaker."
title: Dracula

text: "Good, oh my friend John! Well thought of! Truly Miss Lucy, if she be
title: Dracula

text: sad in the foes that beset her, is at least happy in the friends that
title: Dracula

text: love her. One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides one old
title: Dracula

text: man. Ah yes, I know, friend John; I am not blind! I love you all the
title: Dracula

text: more for it! Now go."
title: Dracula

text: In the hall I met Quincey Morris, with a telegram for Arthur telling him
title: Dracula

text: that Mrs. Westenra was dead; that Lucy also had been ill, but was now
title: Dracula

text: going on better; and that Van Helsing and I were with her. I told him
title: Dracula

text: where I was going, and he hurried me out, but as I was going said:--
title: Dracula

text: "When you come back, Jack, may I have two words with you all to
title: Dracula

text: ourselves?" I nodded in reply and went out. I found no difficulty about
title: Dracula

text: the registration, and arranged with the local undertaker to come up in
title: Dracula

text: the evening to measure for the coffin and to make arrangements.
title: Dracula

text: When I got back Quincey was waiting for me. I told him I would see him
title: Dracula

text: as soon as I knew about Lucy, and went up to her room. She was still
title: Dracula

text: sleeping, and the Professor seemingly had not moved from his seat at her
title: Dracula

text: side. From his putting his finger to his lips, I gathered that he
title: Dracula

text: expected her to wake before long and was afraid of forestalling nature.
title: Dracula

text: So I went down to Quincey and took him into the breakfast-room, where
title: Dracula

text: the blinds were not drawn down, and which was a little more cheerful, or
title: Dracula

text: rather less cheerless, than the other rooms. When we were alone, he said
title: Dracula

text: to me:--
title: Dracula

text: "Jack Seward, I don't want to shove myself in anywhere where I've no
title: Dracula

text: right to be; but this is no ordinary case. You know I loved that girl
title: Dracula

text: and wanted to marry her; but, although that's all past and gone, I can't
title: Dracula

text: help feeling anxious about her all the same. What is it that's wrong
title: Dracula

text: with her? The Dutchman--and a fine old fellow he is; I can see
title: Dracula

text: that--said, that time you two came into the room, that you must have
title: Dracula

text: _another_ transfusion of blood, and that both you and he were exhausted.
title: Dracula

text: Now I know well that you medical men speak _in camera_, and that a man
title: Dracula

text: must not expect to know what they consult about in private. But this is
title: Dracula

text: no common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part. Is not that
title: Dracula

text: so?"
title: Dracula

text: "That's so," I said, and he went on:--
title: Dracula

text: "I take it that both you and Van Helsing had done already what I did
title: Dracula

text: to-day. Is not that so?"
title: Dracula

text: "That's so."
title: Dracula

text: "And I guess Art was in it too. When I saw him four days ago down at his
title: Dracula

text: own place he looked queer. I have not seen anything pulled down so quick
title: Dracula

text: since I was on the Pampas and had a mare that I was fond of go to grass
title: Dracula

text: all in a night. One of those big bats that they call vampires had got at
title: Dracula

text: her in the night, and what with his gorge and the vein left open, there
title: Dracula

text: wasn't enough blood in her to let her stand up, and I had to put a
title: Dracula

text: bullet through her as she lay. Jack, if you may tell me without
title: Dracula

text: betraying confidence, Arthur was the first, is not that so?" As he spoke
title: Dracula

text: the poor fellow looked terribly anxious. He was in a torture of suspense
title: Dracula

text: regarding the woman he loved, and his utter ignorance of the terrible
title: Dracula

text: mystery which seemed to surround her intensified his pain. His very
title: Dracula

text: heart was bleeding, and it took all the manhood of him--and there was a
title: Dracula

text: royal lot of it, too--to keep him from breaking down. I paused before
title: Dracula

text: answering, for I felt that I must not betray anything which the
title: Dracula

text: Professor wished kept secret; but already he knew so much, and guessed
title: Dracula

text: so much, that there could be no reason for not answering, so I answered
title: Dracula

text: in the same phrase: "That's so."
title: Dracula

text: "And how long has this been going on?"
title: Dracula

text: "About ten days."
title: Dracula

text: "Ten days! Then I guess, Jack Seward, that that poor pretty creature
title: Dracula

text: that we all love has had put into her veins within that time the blood
title: Dracula

text: of four strong men. Man alive, her whole body wouldn't hold it." Then,
title: Dracula

text: coming close to me, he spoke in a fierce half-whisper: "What took it
title: Dracula

text: out?"
title: Dracula

text: I shook my head. "That," I said, "is the crux. Van Helsing is simply
title: Dracula

text: frantic about it, and I am at my wits' end. I can't even hazard a guess.
title: Dracula

text: There has been a series of little circumstances which have thrown out
title: Dracula

text: all our calculations as to Lucy being properly watched. But these shall
title: Dracula

text: not occur again. Here we stay until all be well--or ill." Quincey held
title: Dracula

text: out his hand. "Count me in," he said. "You and the Dutchman will tell me
title: Dracula

text: what to do, and I'll do it."
title: Dracula

text: When she woke late in the afternoon, Lucy's first movement was to feel
title: Dracula

text: in her breast, and, to my surprise, produced the paper which Van Helsing
title: Dracula

text: had given me to read. The careful Professor had replaced it where it had
title: Dracula

text: come from, lest on waking she should be alarmed. Her eye then lit on Van
title: Dracula

text: Helsing and on me too, and gladdened. Then she looked around the room,
title: Dracula

text: and seeing where she was, shuddered; she gave a loud cry, and put her
title: Dracula

text: poor thin hands before her pale face. We both understood what that
title: Dracula

text: meant--that she had realised to the full her mother's death; so we tried
title: Dracula

text: what we could to comfort her. Doubtless sympathy eased her somewhat, but
title: Dracula

text: she was very low in thought and spirit, and wept silently and weakly for
title: Dracula

text: a long time. We told her that either or both of us would now remain with
title: Dracula

text: her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her. Towards dusk she fell
title: Dracula

text: into a doze. Here a very odd thing occurred. Whilst still asleep she
title: Dracula

text: took the paper from her breast and tore it in two. Van Helsing stepped
title: Dracula

text: over and took the pieces from her. All the same, however, she went on
title: Dracula

text: with the action of tearing, as though the material were still in her
title: Dracula

text: hands; finally she lifted her hands and opened them as though scattering
title: Dracula

text: the fragments. Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his brows gathered as
title: Dracula

text: if in thought, but he said nothing.
title: Dracula

text: _19 September._--All last night she slept fitfully, being always afraid
title: Dracula

text: to sleep, and something weaker when she woke from it. The Professor and
title: Dracula

text: I took it in turns to watch, and we never left her for a moment
title: Dracula

text: unattended. Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I knew
title: Dracula

text: that all night long he patrolled round and round the house.
title: Dracula

text: When the day came, its searching light showed the ravages in poor Lucy's
title: Dracula

text: strength. She was hardly able to turn her head, and the little
title: Dracula

text: nourishment which she could take seemed to do her no good. At times she
title: Dracula

text: slept, and both Van Helsing and I noticed the difference in her, between
title: Dracula

text: sleeping and waking. Whilst asleep she looked stronger, although more
title: Dracula

text: haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale
title: Dracula

text: gums drawn back from the teeth, which thus looked positively longer and
title: Dracula

text: sharper than usual; when she woke the softness of her eyes evidently
title: Dracula

text: changed the expression, for she looked her own self, although a dying
title: Dracula

text: one. In the afternoon she asked for Arthur, and we telegraphed for him.
title: Dracula

text: Quincey went off to meet him at the station.
title: Dracula

text: When he arrived it was nearly six o'clock, and the sun was setting full
title: Dracula

text: and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more
title: Dracula

text: colour to the pale cheeks. When he saw her, Arthur was simply choking
title: Dracula

text: with emotion, and none of us could speak. In the hours that had passed,
title: Dracula

text: the fits of sleep, or the comatose condition that passed for it, had
title: Dracula

text: grown more frequent, so that the pauses when conversation was possible
title: Dracula

text: were shortened. Arthur's presence, however, seemed to act as a
title: Dracula

text: stimulant; she rallied a little, and spoke to him more brightly than she
title: Dracula

text: had done since we arrived. He too pulled himself together, and spoke as
title: Dracula

text: cheerily as he could, so that the best was made of everything.
title: Dracula

text: It was now nearly one o'clock, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with
title: Dracula

text: her. I am to relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am entering
title: Dracula

text: this on Lucy's phonograph. Until six o'clock they are to try to rest. I
title: Dracula

text: fear that to-morrow will end our watching, for the shock has been too
title: Dracula

text: great; the poor child cannot rally. God help us all.
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "It seems _an age_ since I heard from you, or indeed since I wrote. You
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "Such a sad blow has befallen us. Mr. Hawkins has died very suddenly.
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: and we find it, thank God, unharmed amongst the graves. Yesterday I came
title: Dracula

text: here before sundown, for at sundown the Un-Dead can move. I waited here
title: Dracula

text: all the night till the sun rose, but I saw nothing. It was most probable
title: Dracula

text: that it was because I had laid over the clamps of those doors garlic,
title: Dracula

text: which the Un-Dead cannot bear, and other things which they shun. Last
title: Dracula

text: night there was no exodus, so to-night before the sundown I took away my
title: Dracula

text: garlic and other things. And so it is we find this coffin empty. But
title: Dracula

text: bear with me. So far there is much that is strange. Wait you with me
title: Dracula

text: outside, unseen and unheard, and things much stranger are yet to be.
title: Dracula

text: So"--here he shut the dark slide of his lantern--"now to the outside."

text: He opened the door, and we filed out, he coming last and locking the
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: asked him what it was that he was doing. Arthur and Quincey drew near

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "And is that stuff you have put there going to do it?" asked Quincey.

text: "Great Scott! Is this a game?"
title: Dracula

text: "It is."
title: Dracula

text: "What is that which you are using?" This time the question was by
title: Dracula

text: Arthur. Van Helsing reverently lifted his hat as he answered:--
title: Dracula

text: "The Host. I brought it from Amsterdam. I have an Indulgence." It was an
title: Dracula

text: answer that appalled the most sceptical of us, and we felt individually
title: Dracula

text: that in the presence of such earnest purpose as the Professor's, a
title: Dracula

text: purpose which could thus use the to him most sacred of things, it was
title: Dracula

text: impossible to distrust. In respectful silence we took the places
title: Dracula

text: assigned to us close round the tomb, but hidden from the sight of any
title: Dracula

text: one approaching. I pitied the others, especially Arthur. I had myself
title: Dracula

text: been apprenticed by my former visits to this watching horror; and yet I,
title: Dracula

text: who had up to an hour ago repudiated the proofs, felt my heart sink
title: Dracula

text: within me. Never did tombs look so ghastly white; never did cypress, or
title: Dracula

text: yew, or juniper so seem the embodiment of funereal gloom; never did tree
title: Dracula

text: or grass wave or rustle so ominously; never did bough creak so
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: There was a long spell of silence, a big, aching void, and then from the
title: Dracula

text: Professor a keen "S-s-s-s!" He pointed; and far down the avenue of yews
title: Dracula

text: we saw a white figure advance--a dim white figure, which held something
title: Dracula

text: dark at its breast. The figure stopped, and at the moment a ray of
title: Dracula

text: moonlight fell upon the masses of driving clouds and showed in startling
title: Dracula

text: prominence a dark-haired woman, dressed in the cerements of the grave.
title: Dracula

text: We could not see the face, for it was bent down over what we saw to be a
title: Dracula

text: fair-haired child. There was a pause and a sharp little cry, such as a
title: Dracula

text: child gives in sleep, or a dog as it lies before the fire and dreams. We
title: Dracula

text: were starting forward, but the Professor's warning hand, seen by us as
title: Dracula

text: he stood behind a yew-tree, kept us back; and then as we looked the
title: Dracula

text: white figure moved forwards again. It was now near enough for us to see
title: Dracula

text: clearly, and the moonlight still held. My own heart grew cold as ice,
title: Dracula

text: and I could hear the gasp of Arthur, as we recognised the features of
title: Dracula

text: Lucy Westenra. Lucy Westenra, but yet how changed. The sweetness was
title: Dracula

text: turned to adamantine, heartless cruelty, and the purity to voluptuous
title: Dracula

text: wantonness. Van Helsing stepped out, and, obedient to his gesture, we
title: Dracula

text: all advanced too; the four of us ranged in a line before the door of the
title: Dracula

text: tomb. Van Helsing raised his lantern and drew the slide; by the
title: Dracula

text: concentrated light that fell on Lucy's face we could see that the lips
title: Dracula

text: were crimson with fresh blood, and that the stream had trickled over her
title: Dracula

text: chin and stained the purity of her lawn death-robe.
title: Dracula

text: We shuddered with horror. I could see by the tremulous light that even
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing's iron nerve had failed. Arthur was next to me, and if I had
title: Dracula

text: not seized his arm and held him up, he would have fallen.
title: Dracula

text: When Lucy--I call the thing that was before us Lucy because it bore her
title: Dracula

text: shape--saw us she drew back with an angry snarl, such as a cat gives
title: Dracula

text: when taken unawares; then her eyes ranged over us. Lucy's eyes in form
title: Dracula

text: and colour; but Lucy's eyes unclean and full of hell-fire, instead of
title: Dracula

text: the pure, gentle orbs we knew. At that moment the remnant of my love
title: Dracula

text: passed into hate and loathing; had she then to be killed, I could have
title: Dracula

text: done it with savage delight. As she looked, her eyes blazed with unholy
title: Dracula

text: light, and the face became wreathed with a voluptuous smile. Oh, God,
title: Dracula

text: how it made me shudder to see it! With a careless motion, she flung to
title: Dracula

text: the ground, callous as a devil, the child that up to now she had
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: over a bone. The child gave a sharp cry, and lay there moaning. There
title: Dracula

text: was a cold-bloodedness in the act which wrung a groan from Arthur; when

text: she advanced to him with outstretched arms and a wanton smile he fell
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: She still advanced, however, and with a languorous, voluptuous grace,
title: Dracula

text: said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Come to me, Arthur. Leave these others and come to me. My arms are
title: Dracula

text: hungry for you. Come, and we can rest together. Come, my husband, come!"
title: Dracula

text: There was something diabolically sweet in her tones--something of the
title: Dracula

text: tingling of glass when struck--which rang through the brains even of us
title: Dracula

text: who heard the words addressed to another. As for Arthur, he seemed under
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: suddenly distorted face, full of rage, dashed past him as if to enter
title: Dracula

text: the tomb.

text: When within a foot or two of the door, however, she stopped, as if
title: Dracula

text: arrested by some irresistible force. Then she turned, and her face was
title: Dracula

text: shown in the clear burst of moonlight and by the lamp, which had now no
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: between the lifted crucifix and the sacred closing of her means of
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Arthur and Quincey came home with me, and we tried to cheer each other
title: Dracula

text: _29 September, night._--A little before twelve o'clock we three--Arthur,
title: Dracula

text: Quincey Morris, and myself--called for the Professor. It was odd to
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: When all was ready, Van Helsing said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Before we do anything, let me tell you this; it is out of the lore and
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
