title: Dracula

text: ripples from a stone thrown in the water. Friend Arthur, if you had met
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: children whose blood she suck are not as yet so much the worse; but if
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: snow:--

text: Outside the air was sweet, the sun shone, and the birds sang, and it
title: Dracula

text: seemed as if all nature were tuned to a different pitch. There was
title: Dracula

text: gladness and mirth and peace everywhere, for we were at rest ourselves
title: Dracula

text: on one account, and we were glad, though it was with a tempered joy.
title: Dracula

text: Before we moved away Van Helsing said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Now, my friends, one step of our work is done, one the most harrowing
title: Dracula

text: to ourselves. But there remains a greater task: to find out the author
title: Dracula

text: of all this our sorrow and to stamp him out. I have clues which we can
title: Dracula

text: follow; but it is a long task, and a difficult, and there is danger in
title: Dracula

text: it, and pain. Shall you not all help me? We have learned to believe, all
title: Dracula

text: of us--is it not so? And since so, do we not see our duty? Yes! And do
title: Dracula

text: we not promise to go on to the bitter end?"
title: Dracula

text: Each in turn, we took his hand, and the promise was made. Then said the
title: Dracula

text: Professor as we moved off:--
title: Dracula

text: "Two nights hence you shall meet with me and dine together at seven of
title: Dracula

text: the clock with friend John. I shall entreat two others, two that you
title: Dracula

text: know not as yet; and I shall be ready to all our work show and our plans
title: Dracula

text: unfold. Friend John, you come with me home, for I have much to consult
title: Dracula

text: about, and you can help me. To-night I leave for Amsterdam, but shall
title: Dracula

text: return to-morrow night. And then begins our great quest. But first I
title: Dracula

text: shall have much to say, so that you may know what is to do and to dread.
title: Dracula

text: Then our promise shall be made to each other anew; for there is a
title: Dracula

text: terrible task before us, and once our feet are on the ploughshare we
title: Dracula

text: must not draw back."
title: Dracula

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: Dracula

text: DR. SEWARD'S DIARY--_continued_
title: Dracula

text: When we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram
title: Dracula

text: waiting for him:--
title: Dracula

text: "Am coming up by train. Jonathan at Whitby. Important news.--MINA
title: Dracula

text: HARKER."
title: Dracula

text: The Professor was delighted. "Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina," he said,
title: Dracula

text: "pearl among women! She arrive, but I cannot stay. She must go to your
title: Dracula

text: house, friend John. You must meet her at the station. Telegraph her _en
title: Dracula

text: route_, so that she may be prepared."
title: Dracula

text: When the wire was despatched he had a cup of tea; over it he told me of
title: Dracula

text: a diary kept by Jonathan Harker when abroad, and gave me a typewritten
title: Dracula

text: copy of it, as also of Mrs. Harker's diary at Whitby. "Take these," he
title: Dracula

text: said, "and study them well. When I have returned you will be master of
title: Dracula

text: all the facts, and we can then better enter on our inquisition. Keep
title: Dracula

text: them safe, for there is in them much of treasure. You will need all your
title: Dracula

text: faith, even you who have had such an experience as that of to-day. What
title: Dracula

text: is here told," he laid his hand heavily and gravely on the packet of
title: Dracula

text: papers as he spoke, "may be the beginning of the end to you and me and
title: Dracula

text: many another; or it may sound the knell of the Un-Dead who walk the
title: Dracula

text: earth. Read all, I pray you, with the open mind; and if you can add in
title: Dracula

text: any way to the story here told do so, for it is all-important. You have
title: Dracula

text: kept diary of all these so strange things; is it not so? Yes! Then we
title: Dracula

text: shall go through all these together when we meet." He then made ready
title: Dracula

text: for his departure, and shortly after drove off to Liverpool Street. I
title: Dracula

text: took my way to Paddington, where I arrived about fifteen minutes before
title: Dracula

text: the train came in.
title: Dracula

text: The crowd melted away, after the bustling fashion common to arrival
title: Dracula

text: platforms; and I was beginning to feel uneasy, lest I might miss my
title: Dracula

text: guest, when a sweet-faced, dainty-looking girl stepped up to me, and,
title: Dracula

text: after a quick glance, said: "Dr. Seward, is it not?"
title: Dracula

text: "And you are Mrs. Harker!" I answered at once; whereupon she held out
title: Dracula

text: her hand.
title: Dracula

text: "I knew you from the description of poor dear Lucy; but----" She stopped
title: Dracula

text: suddenly, and a quick blush overspread her face.
title: Dracula

text: The blush that rose to my own cheeks somehow set us both at ease, for it
title: Dracula

text: was a tacit answer to her own. I got her luggage, which included a
title: Dracula

text: typewriter, and we took the Underground to Fenchurch Street, after I had
title: Dracula

text: sent a wire to my housekeeper to have a sitting-room and bedroom
title: Dracula

text: prepared at once for Mrs. Harker.
title: Dracula

text: In due time we arrived. She knew, of course, that the place was a
title: Dracula

text: lunatic asylum, but I could see that she was unable to repress a shudder
title: Dracula

text: when we entered.
title: Dracula

text: She told me that, if she might, she would come presently to my study, as
title: Dracula

text: she had much to say. So here I am finishing my entry in my phonograph
title: Dracula

text: diary whilst I await her. As yet I have not had the chance of looking at
title: Dracula

text: the papers which Van Helsing left with me, though they lie open before
title: Dracula

text: me. I must get her interested in something, so that I may have an
title: Dracula

text: opportunity of reading them. She does not know how precious time is, or
title: Dracula

text: what a task we have in hand. I must be careful not to frighten her. Here
title: Dracula

text: she is!
title: Dracula

text: _Mina Harker's Journal._
title: Dracula

text: _29 September._--After I had tidied myself, I went down to Dr. Seward's
title: Dracula

text: study. At the door I paused a moment, for I thought I heard him talking
title: Dracula

text: with some one. As, however, he had pressed me to be quick, I knocked at
title: Dracula

text: the door, and on his calling out, "Come in," I entered.
title: Dracula

text: To my intense surprise, there was no one with him. He was quite alone,
title: Dracula

text: and on the table opposite him was what I knew at once from the
title: Dracula

text: description to be a phonograph. I had never seen one, and was much
title: Dracula

text: interested.
title: Dracula

text: "I hope I did not keep you waiting," I said; "but I stayed at the door
title: Dracula

text: as I heard you talking, and thought there was some one with you."
title: Dracula

text: "Oh," he replied with a smile, "I was only entering my diary."
title: Dracula

text: "Your diary?" I asked him in surprise.
title: Dracula

text: "Yes," he answered. "I keep it in this." As he spoke he laid his hand on
title: Dracula

text: the phonograph. I felt quite excited over it, and blurted out:--
title: Dracula

text: "Why, this beats even shorthand! May I hear it say something?"
title: Dracula

text: "Certainly," he replied with alacrity, and stood up to put it in train
title: Dracula

text: for speaking. Then he paused, and a troubled look overspread his face.
title: Dracula

text: "The fact is," he began awkwardly, "I only keep my diary in it; and as
title: Dracula

text: it is entirely--almost entirely--about my cases, it may be awkward--that
title: Dracula

text: is, I mean----" He stopped, and I tried to help him out of his
title: Dracula

text: embarrassment:--
title: Dracula

text: "You helped to attend dear Lucy at the end. Let me hear how she died;
title: Dracula

text: for all that I know of her, I shall be very grateful. She was very, very
title: Dracula

text: dear to me."
title: Dracula

text: To my surprise, he answered, with a horrorstruck look in his face:--
title: Dracula

text: "Tell you of her death? Not for the wide world!"
title: Dracula

text: "Why not?" I asked, for some grave, terrible feeling was coming over me.
title: Dracula

text: Again he paused, and I could see that he was trying to invent an excuse.
title: Dracula

text: At length he stammered out:--
title: Dracula

text: "You see, I do not know how to pick out any particular part of the
title: Dracula

text: diary." Even while he was speaking an idea dawned upon him, and he said
title: Dracula

text: with unconscious simplicity, in a different voice, and with the naïveté
title: Dracula

text: of a child: "That's quite true, upon my honour. Honest Indian!" I could
title: Dracula

text: not but smile, at which he grimaced. "I gave myself away that time!" he
title: Dracula

text: said. "But do you know that, although I have kept the diary for months
title: Dracula

text: past, it never once struck me how I was going to find any particular
title: Dracula

text: part of it in case I wanted to look it up?" By this time my mind was
title: Dracula

text: made up that the diary of a doctor who attended Lucy might have
title: Dracula

text: something to add to the sum of our knowledge of that terrible Being, and
title: Dracula

text: I said boldly:--
title: Dracula

text: "Then, Dr. Seward, you had better let me copy it out for you on my
title: Dracula

text: typewriter." He grew to a positively deathly pallor as he said:--
title: Dracula

text: "No! no! no! For all the world, I wouldn't let you know that terrible
title: Dracula

text: story!"
title: Dracula

text: Then it was terrible; my intuition was right! For a moment I thought,
title: Dracula

text: and as my eyes ranged the room, unconsciously looking for something or
title: Dracula

text: some opportunity to aid me, they lit on a great batch of typewriting on
title: Dracula

text: the table. His eyes caught the look in mine, and, without his thinking,
title: Dracula

text: followed their direction. As they saw the parcel he realised my meaning.
title: Dracula

text: "You do not know me," I said. "When you have read those papers--my own
title: Dracula

text: diary and my husband's also, which I have typed--you will know me
title: Dracula

text: better. I have not faltered in giving every thought of my own heart in
title: Dracula

text: this cause; but, of course, you do not know me--yet; and I must not
title: Dracula

text: expect you to trust me so far."
title: Dracula

text: He is certainly a man of noble nature; poor dear Lucy was right about
title: Dracula

text: him. He stood up and opened a large drawer, in which were arranged in
title: Dracula

text: order a number of hollow cylinders of metal covered with dark wax, and
title: Dracula

text: said:--
title: Dracula

text: "You are quite right. I did not trust you because I did not know you.
title: Dracula

text: But I know you now; and let me say that I should have known you long
title: Dracula

text: ago. I know that Lucy told you of me; she told me of you too. May I make
title: Dracula

text: the only atonement in my power? Take the cylinders and hear them--the
title: Dracula

text: first half-dozen of them are personal to me, and they will not horrify
title: Dracula

text: you; then you will know me better. Dinner will by then be ready. In the
title: Dracula

text: meantime I shall read over some of these documents, and shall be better
title: Dracula

text: able to understand certain things." He carried the phonograph himself up
title: Dracula

text: to my sitting-room and adjusted it for me. Now I shall learn something
title: Dracula

text: pleasant, I am sure; for it will tell me the other side of a true love
title: Dracula

text: episode of which I know one side already....
title: Dracula

text: _Dr. Seward's Diary._
title: Dracula

text: _29 September._--I was so absorbed in that wonderful diary of Jonathan
title: Dracula

text: Harker and that other of his wife that I let the time run on without
title: Dracula

text: thinking. Mrs. Harker was not down when the maid came to announce
title: Dracula

text: dinner, so I said: "She is possibly tired; let dinner wait an hour," and
title: Dracula

text: I went on with my work. I had just finished Mrs. Harker's diary, when
title: Dracula

text: she came in. She looked sweetly pretty, but very sad, and her eyes were
title: Dracula

text: flushed with crying. This somehow moved me much. Of late I have had
title: Dracula

text: cause for tears, God knows! but the relief of them was denied me; and
title: Dracula

text: now the sight of those sweet eyes, brightened with recent tears, went
title: Dracula

text: straight to my heart. So I said as gently as I could:--
title: Dracula

text: "I greatly fear I have distressed you."
title: Dracula

text: "Oh, no, not distressed me," she replied, "but I have been more touched
title: Dracula

text: than I can say by your grief. That is a wonderful machine, but it is
title: Dracula

text: cruelly true. It told me, in its very tones, the anguish of your heart.
title: Dracula

text: It was like a soul crying out to Almighty God. No one must hear them
title: Dracula

text: spoken ever again! See, I have tried to be useful. I have copied out the
title: Dracula

text: words on my typewriter, and none other need now hear your heart beat, as
title: Dracula

text: I did."
title: Dracula

text: "No one need ever know, shall ever know," I said in a low voice. She
title: Dracula

text: laid her hand on mine and said very gravely:--
title: Dracula

text: "Ah, but they must!"
title: Dracula

text: "Must! But why?" I asked.
title: Dracula

text: "Because it is a part of the terrible story, a part of poor dear Lucy's
title: Dracula

text: death and all that led to it; because in the struggle which we have
title: Dracula

text: before us to rid the earth of this terrible monster we must have all
title: Dracula

text: the knowledge and all the help which we can get. I think that the
title: Dracula

text: cylinders which you gave me contained more than you intended me to know;
title: Dracula

text: but I can see that there are in your record many lights to this dark
title: Dracula

text: mystery. You will let me help, will you not? I know all up to a certain
title: Dracula

text: point; and I see already, though your diary only took me to 7 September,
title: Dracula

text: how poor Lucy was beset, and how her terrible doom was being wrought
title: Dracula

text: out. Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van
title: Dracula

text: Helsing saw us. He is gone to Whitby to get more information, and he
title: Dracula

text: will be here to-morrow to help us. We need have no secrets amongst us;
title: Dracula

text: working together and with absolute trust, we can surely be stronger than
title: Dracula

text: if some of us were in the dark." She looked at me so appealingly, and at
title: Dracula

text: the same time manifested such courage and resolution in her bearing,
title: Dracula

text: that I gave in at once to her wishes. "You shall," I said, "do as you
title: Dracula

text: like in the matter. God forgive me if I do wrong! There are terrible
title: Dracula

text: things yet to learn of; but if you have so far travelled on the road to
title: Dracula

text: poor Lucy's death, you will not be content, I know, to remain in the
title: Dracula

text: dark. Nay, the end--the very end--may give you a gleam of peace. Come,
title: Dracula

text: there is dinner. We must keep one another strong for what is before us;
title: Dracula

text: we have a cruel and dreadful task. When you have eaten you shall learn
title: Dracula

text: the rest, and I shall answer any questions you ask--if there be anything
title: Dracula

text: which you do not understand, though it was apparent to us who were
title: Dracula

text: present."
title: Dracula

text: _Mina Harker's Journal._
title: Dracula

text: _29 September._--After dinner I came with Dr. Seward to his study. He
title: Dracula

text: brought back the phonograph from my room, and I took my typewriter. He
title: Dracula

text: placed me in a comfortable chair, and arranged the phonograph so that I
title: Dracula

text: could touch it without getting up, and showed me how to stop it in case
title: Dracula

text: I should want to pause. Then he very thoughtfully took a chair, with his
title: Dracula

text: back to me, so that I might be as free as possible, and began to read. I
title: Dracula

text: put the forked metal to my ears and listened.
title: Dracula

text: When the terrible story of Lucy's death, and--and all that followed, was
title: Dracula

text: done, I lay back in my chair powerless. Fortunately I am not of a
title: Dracula

text: fainting disposition. When Dr. Seward saw me he jumped up with a
title: Dracula

text: horrified exclamation, and hurriedly taking a case-bottle from a
title: Dracula

text: cupboard, gave me some brandy, which in a few minutes somewhat restored
title: Dracula

text: me. My brain was all in a whirl, and only that there came through all
title: Dracula

text: the multitude of horrors, the holy ray of light that my dear, dear Lucy
title: Dracula

text: was at last at peace, I do not think I could have borne it without
title: Dracula

text: making a scene. It is all so wild, and mysterious, and strange that if I
title: Dracula

text: had not known Jonathan's experience in Transylvania I could not have
title: Dracula

text: believed. As it was, I didn't know what to believe, and so got out of my
title: Dracula

text: difficulty by attending to something else. I took the cover off my
title: Dracula

text: typewriter, and said to Dr. Seward:--
title: Dracula

text: "Let me write this all out now. We must be ready for Dr. Van Helsing
title: Dracula

text: when he comes. I have sent a telegram to Jonathan to come on here when
title: Dracula

text: he arrives in London from Whitby. In this matter dates are everything,
title: Dracula

text: and I think that if we get all our material ready, and have every item
title: Dracula

text: put in chronological order, we shall have done much. You tell me that
title: Dracula

text: Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris are coming too. Let us be able to tell him
title: Dracula

text: when they come." He accordingly set the phonograph at a slow pace, and I
title: Dracula

text: began to typewrite from the beginning of the seventh cylinder. I used
title: Dracula

text: manifold, and so took three copies of the diary, just as I had done with
title: Dracula

text: all the rest. It was late when I got through, but Dr. Seward went about
title: Dracula

text: his work of going his round of the patients; when he had finished he
title: Dracula

text: came back and sat near me, reading, so that I did not feel too lonely
title: Dracula

text: whilst I worked. How good and thoughtful he is; the world seems full of
title: Dracula

text: good men--even if there _are_ monsters in it. Before I left him I
title: Dracula

text: remembered what Jonathan put in his diary of the Professor's
title: Dracula

text: perturbation at reading something in an evening paper at the station at
title: Dracula

text: Exeter; so, seeing that Dr. Seward keeps his newspapers, I borrowed the
title: Dracula

text: files of "The Westminster Gazette" and "The Pall Mall Gazette," and took
title: Dracula

text: them to my room. I remember how much "The Dailygraph" and "The Whitby
title: Dracula

text: Gazette," of which I had made cuttings, helped us to understand the
title: Dracula

text: terrible events at Whitby when Count Dracula landed, so I shall look
title: Dracula

text: through the evening papers since then, and perhaps I shall get some new
title: Dracula

text: light. I am not sleepy, and the work will help to keep me quiet.
title: Dracula

text: _Dr. Seward's Diary._
title: Dracula

text: _30 September._--Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock. He had got his
title: Dracula

text: wife's wire just before starting. He is uncommonly clever, if one can
title: Dracula

text: judge from his face, and full of energy. If this journal be true--and
title: Dracula

text: judging by one's own wonderful experiences, it must be--he is also a man
title: Dracula

text: of great nerve. That going down to the vault a second time was a
title: Dracula

text: remarkable piece of daring. After reading his account of it I was
title: Dracula

text: prepared to meet a good specimen of manhood, but hardly the quiet,
title: Dracula

text: business-like gentleman who came here to-day.
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--After lunch Harker and his wife went back to their own room,
title: Dracula

text: and as I passed a while ago I heard the click of the typewriter. They
title: Dracula

text: are hard at it. Mrs. Harker says that they are knitting together in
title: Dracula

text: chronological order every scrap of evidence they have. Harker has got
title: Dracula

text: the letters between the consignee of the boxes at Whitby and the
title: Dracula

text: carriers in London who took charge of them. He is now reading his wife's
title: Dracula

text: typescript of my diary. I wonder what they make out of it. Here it
title: Dracula

text: Strange that it never struck me that the very next house might be
title: Dracula

text: the Count's hiding-place! Goodness knows that we had enough clues
title: Dracula

text: from the conduct of the patient Renfield! The bundle of letters
title: Dracula

text: relating to the purchase of the house were with the typescript. Oh,
title: Dracula

text: if we had only had them earlier we might have saved poor Lucy!
title: Dracula

text: Stop; that way madness lies! Harker has gone back, and is again
title: Dracula

text: collating his material. He says that by dinner-time they will be
title: Dracula

text: able to show a whole connected narrative. He thinks that in the
title: Dracula

text: meantime I should see Renfield, as hitherto he has been a sort of
title: Dracula

text: index to the coming and going of the Count. I hardly see this yet,
title: Dracula

text: but when I get at the dates I suppose I shall. What a good thing
title: Dracula

text: that Mrs. Harker put my cylinders into type! We never could have
title: Dracula

text: found the dates otherwise....
title: Dracula

text: I found Renfield sitting placidly in his room with his hands
title: Dracula

text: folded, smiling benignly. At the moment he seemed as sane as any
title: Dracula

text: one I ever saw. I sat down and talked with him on a lot of
title: Dracula

text: subjects, all of which he treated naturally. He then, of his own
title: Dracula

text: accord, spoke of going home, a subject he has never mentioned to my
title: Dracula

text: knowledge during his sojourn here. In fact, he spoke quite
title: Dracula

text: confidently of getting his discharge at once. I believe that, had I
title: Dracula

text: not had the chat with Harker and read the letters and the dates of
title: Dracula

text: his outbursts, I should have been prepared to sign for him after a
title: Dracula

text: brief time of observation. As it is, I am darkly suspicious. All
title: Dracula

text: those outbreaks were in some way linked with the proximity of the
title: Dracula

text: Count. What then does this absolute content mean? Can it be that
title: Dracula

text: his instinct is satisfied as to the vampire's ultimate triumph?
title: Dracula

text: Stay; he is himself zoöphagous, and in his wild ravings outside the
title: Dracula

text: chapel door of the deserted house he always spoke of "master." This
title: Dracula

text: all seems confirmation of our idea. However, after a while I came
title: Dracula

text: away; my friend is just a little too sane at present to make it
title: Dracula

text: safe to probe him too deep with questions. He might begin to think,
title: Dracula

text: and then--! So I came away. I mistrust these quiet moods of his; so
title: Dracula

text: I have given the attendant a hint to look closely after him, and to
title: Dracula

text: have a strait-waistcoat ready in case of need.
title: Dracula

text: _Jonathan Harker's Journal._
title: Dracula

text: _29 September, in train to London._--When I received Mr. Billington's
title: Dracula

text: courteous message that he would give me any information in his power I
title: Dracula

text: thought it best to go down to Whitby and make, on the spot, such
title: Dracula

text: inquiries as I wanted. It was now my object to trace that horrid cargo
title: Dracula

text: of the Count's to its place in London. Later, we may be able to deal
title: Dracula

text: with it. Billington junior, a nice lad, met me at the station, and
title: Dracula

text: brought me to his father's house, where they had decided that I must
title: Dracula

text: stay the night. They are hospitable, with true Yorkshire hospitality:
title: Dracula

text: give a guest everything, and leave him free to do as he likes. They all
title: Dracula

text: knew that I was busy, and that my stay was short, and Mr. Billington had
title: Dracula

text: ready in his office all the papers concerning the consignment of boxes.
title: Dracula

text: It gave me almost a turn to see again one of the letters which I had
title: Dracula

text: seen on the Count's table before I knew of his diabolical plans.
title: Dracula

text: Everything had been carefully thought out, and done systematically and
title: Dracula

text: with precision. He seemed to have been prepared for every obstacle which
title: Dracula

text: might be placed by accident in the way of his intentions being carried
title: Dracula

text: out. To use an Americanism, he had "taken no chances," and the absolute
title: Dracula

text: accuracy with which his instructions were fulfilled, was simply the
title: Dracula

text: logical result of his care. I saw the invoice, and took note of it:
title: Dracula

text: "Fifty cases of common earth, to be used for experimental purposes."
title: Dracula

text: Also the copy of letter to Carter Paterson, and their reply; of both of
title: Dracula

text: these I got copies. This was all the information Mr. Billington could
title: Dracula

text: give me, so I went down to the port and saw the coastguards, the Customs

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _3 October._--The time seemed terribly long whilst we were waiting for
title: Dracula

text: the coming of Godalming and Quincey Morris. The Professor tried to keep
title: Dracula

text: our minds active by using them all the time. I could see his beneficent
title: Dracula

text: purpose, by the side glances which he threw from time to time at Harker.
title: Dracula

text: The poor fellow is overwhelmed in a misery that is appalling to see.
title: Dracula

text: Last night he was a frank, happy-looking man, with strong, youthful
title: Dracula

text: face, full of energy, and with dark brown hair. To-day he is a drawn,
title: Dracula

text: haggard old man, whose white hair matches well with the hollow burning
title: Dracula

text: eyes and grief-written lines of his face. His energy is still intact; in
title: Dracula

text: fact, he is like a living flame. This may yet be his salvation, for, if
title: Dracula

text: all go well, it will tide him over the despairing period; he will then,
title: Dracula

text: in a kind of way, wake again to the realities of life. Poor fellow, I
title: Dracula

text: thought my own trouble was bad enough, but his----! The Professor knows
title: Dracula

text: this well enough, and is doing his best to keep his mind active. What he
title: Dracula

text: has been saying was, under the circumstances, of absorbing interest. So
title: Dracula

text: well as I can remember, here it is:--
title: Dracula

text: "I have studied, over and over again since they came into my hands, all
title: Dracula

text: the papers relating to this monster; and the more I have studied, the
title: Dracula

text: greater seems the necessity to utterly stamp him out. All through there
title: Dracula

text: are signs of his advance; not only of his power, but of his knowledge of
title: Dracula

text: it. As I learned from the researches of my friend Arminus of Buda-Pesth,
title: Dracula

text: he was in life a most wonderful man. Soldier, statesman, and
title: Dracula

text: alchemist--which latter was the highest development of the
title: Dracula

text: science-knowledge of his time. He had a mighty brain, a learning beyond
title: Dracula

text: compare, and a heart that knew no fear and no remorse. He dared even to
title: Dracula

text: attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time
title: Dracula

text: that he did not essay. Well, in him the brain powers survived the
title: Dracula

text: physical death; though it would seem that memory was not all complete.
title: Dracula

text: In some faculties of mind he has been, and is, only a child; but he is
title: Dracula

text: growing, and some things that were childish at the first are now of
title: Dracula

text: man's stature. He is experimenting, and doing it well; and if it had not
title: Dracula

text: been that we have crossed his path he would be yet--he may be yet if we
title: Dracula

text: fail--the father or furtherer of a new order of beings, whose road must
title: Dracula

text: lead through Death, not Life."
title: Dracula

text: Harker groaned and said, "And this is all arrayed against my darling!
title: Dracula

text: But how is he experimenting? The knowledge may help us to defeat him!"
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: We had dinner and went to bed early. To-morrow we are to see the
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: on the boat between sunrise and sunset. The Count, even if he takes the
title: Dracula

text: form of a bat, cannot cross the running water of his own volition, and
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: and we are well supplied with money. We have only to make sure that the
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing and I were a little alarmed about Mrs. Harker to-day. About
title: Dracula

text: noon she got into a sort of lethargy which we did not like; although we
title: Dracula

text: kept silence to the others, we were neither of us happy about it. She
title: Dracula

text: had been restless all the morning, so that we were at first glad to know
title: Dracula

text: that she was sleeping. When, however, her husband mentioned casually
title: Dracula

text: that she was sleeping so soundly that he could not wake her, we went to
title: Dracula

text: her room to see for ourselves. She was breathing naturally and looked so
title: Dracula

text: well and peaceful that we agreed that the sleep was better for her than
title: Dracula

text: anything else. Poor girl, she has so much to forget that it is no wonder
title: Dracula

text: that sleep, if it brings oblivion to her, does her good.
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--Our opinion was justified, for when after a refreshing sleep
title: Dracula

text: of some hours she woke up, she seemed brighter and better than she had
title: Dracula

text: been for days. At sunset she made the usual hypnotic report. Wherever he
title: Dracula

text: may be in the Black Sea, the Count is hurrying to his destination. To
title: Dracula

text: his doom, I trust!

text: _26 October._--Another day and no tidings of the _Czarina Catherine_.
title: Dracula

text: She ought to be here by now. That she is still journeying _somewhere_ is
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _28 October._--When the telegram came announcing the arrival in Galatz I
title: Dracula

text: do not think it was such a shock to any of us as might have been
title: Dracula

text: expected. True, we did not know whence, or how, or when, the bolt would
title: Dracula

text: come; but I think we all expected that something strange would happen.
title: Dracula

text: The delay of arrival at Varna made us individually satisfied that things
title: Dracula

text: would not be just as we had expected; we only waited to learn where the
title: Dracula

text: change would occur. None the less, however, was it a surprise. I suppose
title: Dracula

text: that nature works on such a hopeful basis that we believe against
title: Dracula

text: ourselves that things will be as they ought to be, not as we should know
title: Dracula

text: that they will be. Transcendentalism is a beacon to the angels, even if
title: Dracula

text: it be a will-o'-the-wisp to man. It was an odd experience and we all
title: Dracula

text: took it differently. Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a
title: Dracula

text: moment, as though in remonstrance with the Almighty; but he said not a
title: Dracula

text: word, and in a few seconds stood up with his face sternly set. Lord
title: Dracula

text: Godalming grew very pale, and sat breathing heavily. I was myself half
title: Dracula

text: stunned and looked in wonder at one after another. Quincey Morris
title: Dracula

text: tightened his belt with that quick movement which I knew so well; in our
title: Dracula

text: old wandering days it meant "action." Mrs. Harker grew ghastly white, so
title: Dracula

text: that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she folded her hands
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: the great Kukri knife and rested there. "When does the next train start
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: "Then, as he is criminal he is selfish; and as his intellect is small
title: Dracula

text: and his action is based on selfishness, he confines himself to one
title: Dracula

text: purpose. That purpose is remorseless. As he fled back over the Danube,
title: Dracula

text: leaving his forces to be cut to pieces, so now he is intent on being
title: Dracula

text: safe, careless of all. So his own selfishness frees my soul somewhat
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: night. I felt it! Oh, I felt it! Thank God, for His great mercy! My soul
title: Dracula

text: is freer than it has been since that awful hour; and all that haunts me
title: Dracula

text: is a fear lest in some trance or dream he may have used my knowledge for
title: Dracula

text: his ends." The Professor stood up:--
title: Dracula

text: "He has so used your mind; and by it he has left us here in Varna,
title: Dracula

text: whilst the ship that carried him rushed through enveloping fog up to
title: Dracula

text: Galatz, where, doubtless, he had made preparation for escaping from us.
title: Dracula

text: But his child-mind only saw so far; and it may be that, as ever is in
title: Dracula

text: God's Providence, the very thing that the evil-doer most reckoned on for
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: in his own snare, as the great Psalmist says. For now that he think he
title: Dracula

text: is free from every trace of us all, and that he has escaped us with so
title: Dracula

text: many hours to him, then his selfish child-brain will whisper him to
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: in spirit, as you have as yet done in your times of freedom, when the
title: Dracula

text: sun rise and set. At such times you go by my volition and not by his;
title: Dracula

text: and this power to good of you and others, as you have won from your
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: it not, and to guard himself have even cut himself off from his
title: Dracula

text: knowledge of our where. We, however, are not selfish, and we believe
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: DR. SEWARD'S DIARY
title: Dracula

text: _29 October._--This is written in the train from Varna to Galatz. Last
title: Dracula

text: night we all assembled a little before the time of sunset. Each of us
title: Dracula

text: had done his work as well as he could; so far as thought, and endeavour,
title: Dracula

text: and opportunity go, we are prepared for the whole of our journey, and
title: Dracula

text: for our work when we get to Galatz. When the usual time came round Mrs.
title: Dracula

text: Harker prepared herself for her hypnotic effort; and after a longer and
title: Dracula

text: more serious effort on the part of Van Helsing than has been usually
title: Dracula

text: necessary, she sank into the trance. Usually she speaks on a hint; but
title: Dracula

text: this time the Professor had to ask her questions, and to ask them pretty
title: Dracula

text: resolutely, before we could learn anything; at last her answer came:--
title: Dracula

text: "I can see nothing; we are still; there are no waves lapping, but only a
title: Dracula

text: steady swirl of water softly running against the hawser. I can hear
title: Dracula

text: men's voices calling, near and far, and the roll and creak of oars in
title: Dracula

text: the rowlocks. A gun is fired somewhere; the echo of it seems far away.
title: Dracula

text: There is tramping of feet overhead, and ropes and chains are dragged
title: Dracula

text: along. What is this? There is a gleam of light; I can feel the air
title: Dracula

text: blowing upon me."
title: Dracula

text: Here she stopped. She had risen, as if impulsively, from where she lay
title: Dracula

text: on the sofa, and raised both her hands, palms upwards, as if lifting a
title: Dracula

text: weight. Van Helsing and I looked at each other with understanding.
title: Dracula

text: Quincey raised his eyebrows slightly and looked at her intently, whilst
title: Dracula

text: Harker's hand instinctively closed round the hilt of his Kukri. There
title: Dracula

text: was a long pause. We all knew that the time when she could speak was
title: Dracula

text: passing; but we felt that it was useless to say anything. Suddenly she
title: Dracula

text: sat up, and, as she opened her eyes, said sweetly:--
title: Dracula

text: "Would none of you like a cup of tea? You must all be so tired!" We
title: Dracula

text: could only make her happy, and so acquiesced. She bustled off to get
title: Dracula

text: tea; when she had gone Van Helsing said:--
title: Dracula

text: "You see, my friends. _He_ is close to land: he has left his
title: Dracula

text: earth-chest. But he has yet to get on shore. In the night he may lie
title: Dracula

text: hidden somewhere; but if he be not carried on shore, or if the ship do
title: Dracula

text: not touch it, he cannot achieve the land. In such case he can, if it be
title: Dracula

text: in the night, change his form and can jump or fly on shore, as he did
title: Dracula

text: at Whitby. But if the day come before he get on shore, then, unless he
title: Dracula

text: be carried he cannot escape. And if he be carried, then the customs men
title: Dracula

text: may discover what the box contain. Thus, in fine, if he escape not on
title: Dracula

text: shore to-night, or before dawn, there will be the whole day lost to him.
title: Dracula

text: We may then arrive in time; for if he escape not at night we shall come
title: Dracula

text: on him in daytime, boxed up and at our mercy; for he dare not be his
title: Dracula

text: true self, awake and visible, lest he be discovered."
title: Dracula

text: There was no more to be said, so we waited in patience until the dawn;
title: Dracula

text: at which time we might learn more from Mrs. Harker.
title: Dracula

text: Early this morning we listened, with breathless anxiety, for her
title: Dracula

text: response in her trance. The hypnotic stage was even longer in coming
title: Dracula

text: than before; and when it came the time remaining until full sunrise was
title: Dracula

text: so short that we began to despair. Van Helsing seemed to throw his whole
title: Dracula

text: soul into the effort; at last, in obedience to his will she made
title: Dracula

text: reply:--
title: Dracula

text: "All is dark. I hear lapping water, level with me, and some creaking as
title: Dracula

text: of wood on wood." She paused, and the red sun shot up. We must wait till
title: Dracula

text: to-night.
title: Dracula

text: And so it is that we are travelling towards Galatz in an agony of
title: Dracula

text: expectation. We are due to arrive between two and three in the morning;
title: Dracula

text: but already, at Bucharest, we are three hours late, so we cannot
title: Dracula

text: possibly get in till well after sun-up. Thus we shall have two more
title: Dracula

text: hypnotic messages from Mrs. Harker; either or both may possibly throw
title: Dracula

text: more light on what is happening.
title: Dracula

text: _Later._--Sunset has come and gone. Fortunately it came at a time when
title: Dracula

text: there was no distraction; for had it occurred whilst we were at a
title: Dracula

text: station, we might not have secured the necessary calm and isolation.
title: Dracula

text: Mrs. Harker yielded to the hypnotic influence even less readily than
title: Dracula

text: this morning. I am in fear that her power of reading the Count's
title: Dracula

text: sensations may die away, just when we want it most. It seems to me that
title: Dracula

text: her imagination is beginning to work. Whilst she has been in the trance
title: Dracula

text: hitherto she has confined herself to the simplest of facts. If this goes
title: Dracula

text: on it may ultimately mislead us. If I thought that the Count's power
title: Dracula

text: over her would die away equally with her power of knowledge it would be
title: Dracula

text: a happy thought; but I am afraid that it may not be so. When she did
title: Dracula

text: speak, her words were enigmatical:--
title: Dracula

text: "Something is going out; I can feel it pass me like a cold wind. I can
title: Dracula

text: hear, far off, confused sounds--as of men talking in strange tongues,
title: Dracula

text: fierce-falling water, and the howling of wolves." She stopped and a
title: Dracula

text: shudder ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds,
title: Dracula

text: till, at the end, she shook as though in a palsy. She said no more, even
title: Dracula

text: in answer to the Professor's imperative questioning. When she woke from
title: Dracula

text: the trance, she was cold, and exhausted, and languid; but her mind was
title: Dracula

text: all alert. She could not remember anything, but asked what she had said;
title: Dracula

text: when she was told, she pondered over it deeply for a long time and in
title: Dracula

text: silence.

text: _30 October, 7 a. m._--We are near Galatz now, and I may not have time
title: Dracula

text: to write later. Sunrise this morning was anxiously looked for by us all.
title: Dracula

text: Knowing of the increasing difficulty of procuring the hypnotic trance,
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing began his passes earlier than usual. They produced no
title: Dracula

text: effect, however, until the regular time, when she yielded with a still
title: Dracula

text: greater difficulty, only a minute before the sun rose. The Professor
title: Dracula

text: lost no time in his questioning; her answer came with equal quickness:--
title: Dracula

text: "All is dark. I hear water swirling by, level with my ears, and the
title: Dracula

text: creaking of wood on wood. Cattle low far off. There is another sound, a
title: Dracula

text: queer one like----" She stopped and grew white, and whiter still.
title: Dracula

text: "Go on; go on! Speak, I command you!" said Van Helsing in an agonised
title: Dracula

text: voice. At the same time there was despair in his eyes, for the risen sun
title: Dracula

text: was reddening even Mrs. Harker's pale face. She opened her eyes, and we
title: Dracula

text: all started as she said, sweetly and seemingly with the utmost
title: Dracula

text: unconcern:--
title: Dracula

text: "Oh, Professor, why ask me to do what you know I can't? I don't remember
title: Dracula

text: anything." Then, seeing the look of amazement on our faces, she said,
title: Dracula

text: turning from one to the other with a troubled look:--
title: Dracula

text: "What have I said? What have I done? I know nothing, only that I was
title: Dracula

text: lying here, half asleep, and heard you say go on! speak, I command you!'
title: Dracula

text: It seemed so funny to hear you order me about, as if I were a bad
title: Dracula

text: child!"
title: Dracula

text: "Oh, Madam Mina," he said, sadly, "it is proof, if proof be needed, of
title: Dracula

text: how I love and honour you, when a word for your good, spoken more
title: Dracula

text: earnest than ever, can seem so strange because it is to order her whom I
title: Dracula

text: am proud to obey!"
title: Dracula

text: The whistles are sounding; we are nearing Galatz. We are on fire with
title: Dracula

text: anxiety and eagerness.

title: Dracula

text: _30 October._--At nine o'clock Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I called
title: Dracula

text: on Messrs. Mackenzie & Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of
title: Dracula

text: Hapgood. They had received a wire from London, in answer to Lord
title: Dracula

text: Godalming's telegraphed request, asking us to show them any civility in
title: Dracula

text: their power. They were more than kind and courteous, and took us at once
title: Dracula

text: on board the _Czarina Catherine_, which lay at anchor out in the river
title: Dracula

text: harbour. There we saw the Captain, Donelson by name, who told us of his
title: Dracula

text: voyage. He said that in all his life he had never had so favourable a
title: Dracula

text: run.
title: Dracula

text: "Man!" he said, "but it made us afeard, for we expeckit that we should
title: Dracula

text: have to pay for it wi' some rare piece o' ill luck, so as to keep up the
title: Dracula

text: average. It's no canny to run frae London to the Black Sea wi' a wind
title: Dracula

text: ahint ye, as though the Deil himself were blawin' on yer sail for his
title: Dracula

text: ain purpose. An' a' the time we could no speer a thing. Gin we were nigh
title: Dracula

text: a ship, or a port, or a headland, a fog fell on us and travelled wi' us,
title: Dracula

text: till when after it had lifted and we looked out, the deil a thing could
title: Dracula

text: we see. We ran by Gibraltar wi'oot bein' able to signal; an' till we
title: Dracula

text: came to the Dardanelles and had to wait to get our permit to pass, we
title: Dracula

text: never were within hail o' aught. At first I inclined to slack off sail
title: Dracula

text: and beat about till the fog was lifted; but whiles, I thocht that if the
title: Dracula

text: Deil was minded to get us into the Black Sea quick, he was like to do it
title: Dracula

text: whether we would or no. If we had a quick voyage it would be no to our
title: Dracula

text: miscredit wi' the owners, or no hurt to our traffic; an' the Old Mon who
title: Dracula

text: had served his ain purpose wad be decently grateful to us for no
title: Dracula

text: hinderin' him." This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition
title: Dracula

text: and commercial reasoning, aroused Van Helsing, who said:--
title: Dracula

text: "Mine friend, that Devil is more clever than he is thought by some; and
title: Dracula

text: he know when he meet his match!" The skipper was not displeased with the
title: Dracula

text: compliment, and went on:--
title: Dracula

text: "When we got past the Bosphorus the men began to grumble; some o' them,
title: Dracula

text: the Roumanians, came and asked me to heave overboard a big box which had
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: frae London. I had seen them speer at the fellow, and put out their twa
title: Dracula

text: fingers when they saw him, to guard against the evil eye. Man! but the
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: felt a wee bit as they did anent something, though I wouldn't say it was
title: Dracula

text: agin the big box. Well, on we went, and as the fog didn't let up for
title: Dracula

text: five days I joost let the wind carry us; for if the Deil wanted to get
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _Ground of inquiry._--Count Dracula's problem is to get back to his own
title: Dracula

text: place.
title: Dracula

text: (_a_) He must be _brought back_ by some one. This is evident; for had he
title: Dracula

text: power to move himself as he wished he could go either as man, or wolf,
title: Dracula

text: or bat, or in some other way. He evidently fears discovery or
title: Dracula

text: interference, in the state of helplessness in which he must be--confined
title: Dracula

text: as he is between dawn and sunset in his wooden box.
title: Dracula

text: (_b_) _How is he to be taken?_--Here a process of exclusions may help
title: Dracula

text: us. By road, by rail, by water?
title: Dracula

text: 1. _By Road._--There are endless difficulties, especially in leaving the
title: Dracula

text: city.
title: Dracula

text: (_x_) There are people; and people are curious, and investigate. A hint,
title: Dracula

text: a surmise, a doubt as to what might be in the box, would destroy him.
title: Dracula

text: (_y_) There are, or there may be, customs and octroi officers to pass.
title: Dracula

text: (_z_) His pursuers might follow. This is his highest fear; and in order
title: Dracula

text: to prevent his being betrayed he has repelled, so far as he can, even
title: Dracula

text: 2. _By Rail._--There is no one in charge of the box. It would have to
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: _1 November._--All day long we have travelled, and at a good speed. The
title: Dracula

text: horses seem to know that they are being kindly treated, for they go
title: Dracula

text: willingly their full stage at best speed. We have now had so many
title: Dracula

text: changes and find the same thing so constantly that we are encouraged to
title: Dracula

text: think that the journey will be an easy one. Dr. Van Helsing is laconic;
title: Dracula

text: he tells the farmers that he is hurrying to Bistritz, and pays them well
title: Dracula

text: to make the exchange of horses. We get hot soup, or coffee, or tea; and
title: Dracula

text: off we go. It is a lovely country; full of beauties of all imaginable
title: Dracula

text: kinds, and the people are brave, and strong, and simple, and seem full
title: Dracula

text: of nice qualities. They are _very, very_ superstitious. In the first
title: Dracula

text: house where we stopped, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my
title: Dracula

text: forehead, she crossed herself and put out two fingers towards me, to
title: Dracula

text: keep off the evil eye. I believe they went to the trouble of putting an
title: Dracula

text: extra amount of garlic into our food; and I can't abide garlic. Ever
title: Dracula

text: since then I have taken care not to take off my hat or veil, and so have
title: Dracula

text: escaped their suspicions. We are travelling fast, and as we have no
title: Dracula

text: driver with us to carry tales, we go ahead of scandal; but I daresay
title: Dracula

text: that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind us all the way. The
title: Dracula

text: Professor seems tireless; all day he would not take any rest, though he
title: Dracula

text: made me sleep for a long spell. At sunset time he hypnotised me, and he
title: Dracula

text: says that I answered as usual "darkness, lapping water and creaking
title: Dracula

text: wood"; so our enemy is still on the river. I am afraid to think of
title: Dracula

text: Jonathan, but somehow I have now no fear for him, or for myself. I write
title: Dracula

text: this whilst we wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready. Dr.
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing is sleeping, Poor dear, he looks very tired and old and
title: Dracula

text: grey, but his mouth is set as firmly as a conqueror's; even in his sleep
title: Dracula

text: he is instinct with resolution. When we have well started I must make
title: Dracula

text: him rest whilst I drive. I shall tell him that we have days before us,
title: Dracula

text: and we must not break down when most of all his strength will be
title: Dracula

text: needed.... All is ready; we are off shortly.

text: _2 November, morning._--I was successful, and we took turns driving all
title: Dracula

text: night; now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange
title: Dracula

text: heaviness in the air--I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean
title: Dracula

text: that it oppresses us both. It is very cold, and only our warm furs keep
title: Dracula

text: us comfortable. At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered
title: Dracula

text: "darkness, creaking wood and roaring water," so the river is changing as
title: Dracula

text: they ascend. I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of
title: Dracula

text: danger--more than need be; but we are in God's hands.
title: Dracula

text: _2 November, night._--All day long driving. The country gets wilder as
title: Dracula

text: we go, and the great spurs of the Carpathians, which at Veresti seemed
title: Dracula

text: so far from us and so low on the horizon, now seem to gather round us
title: Dracula

text: and tower in front. We both seem in good spirits; I think we make an
title: Dracula

text: effort each to cheer the other; in the doing so we cheer ourselves. Dr.
title: Dracula

text: Van Helsing says that by morning we shall reach the Borgo Pass. The
title: Dracula

text: houses are very few here now, and the Professor says that the last horse
title: Dracula

text: we got will have to go on with us, as we may not be able to change. He
title: Dracula

text: got two in addition to the two we changed, so that now we have a rude
title: Dracula

text: four-in-hand. The dear horses are patient and good, and they give us no
title: Dracula

text: trouble. We are not worried with other travellers, and so even I can
title: Dracula

text: drive. We shall get to the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive
title: Dracula

text: before. So we take it easy, and have each a long rest in turn. Oh, what
title: Dracula

text: will to-morrow bring to us? We go to seek the place where my poor
title: Dracula

text: darling suffered so much. God grant that we may be guided aright, and
title: Dracula

text: that He will deign to watch over my husband and those dear to us both,
title: Dracula

text: and who are in such deadly peril. As for me, I am not worthy in His
title: Dracula

text: sight. Alas! I am unclean to His eyes, and shall be until He may deign
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: affected Madam Mina; she has been so heavy of head all day that she was
title: Dracula

text: not like herself. She sleeps, and sleeps, and sleeps! She who is usual
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: her appetite. She make no entry into her little diary, she who write so
title: Dracula

text: faithful at every pause. Something whisper to me that all is not well.
title: Dracula

text: However, to-night she is more _vif_. Her long sleep all day have refresh
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: I try to hypnotise her, but alas! with no effect; the power has grown
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Now to the historical, for as Madam Mina write not in her stenography, I
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: We got to the Borgo Pass just after sunrise yesterday morning. When I
title: Dracula

text: saw the signs of the dawn I got ready for the hypnotism. We stopped our
title: Dracula

text: carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance. I made a
title: Dracula

text: couch with furs, and Madam Mina, lying down, yield herself as usual, but
title: Dracula

text: more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep. As
title: Dracula

text: before, came the answer: "darkness and the swirling of water." Then she
title: Dracula

text: woke, bright and radiant and we go on our way and soon reach the Pass.
title: Dracula

text: At this time and place, she become all on fire with zeal; some new
title: Dracula

text: guiding power be in her manifested, for she point to a road and say:--
title: Dracula

text: "This is the way."
title: Dracula

text: "How know you it?" I ask.
title: Dracula

text: "Of course I know it," she answer, and with a pause, add: "Have not my
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: At first I think somewhat strange, but soon I see that there be only one
title: Dracula

text: such by-road. It is used but little, and very different from the coach
title: Dracula

text: road from the Bukovina to Bistritz, which is more wide and hard, and
title: Dracula

text: more of use.

text: So we came down this road; when we meet other ways--not always were we
title: Dracula

text: sure that they were roads at all, for they be neglect and light snow
title: Dracula

text: have fallen--the horses know and they only. I give rein to them, and
title: Dracula

text: they go on so patient. By-and-by we find all the things which Jonathan
title: Dracula

text: have note in that wonderful diary of him. Then we go on for long, long
title: Dracula

text: hours and hours. At the first, I tell Madam Mina to sleep; she try, and
title: Dracula

text: she succeed. She sleep all the time; till at the last, I feel myself to
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: look down and find Madam Mina still sleep. It is now not far off sunset
title: Dracula

text: time, and over the snow the light of the sun flow in big yellow flood,

text: For we are going up, and up; and all is oh! so wild and rocky, as though

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: Madam Mina laugh, and I turn and look at her. She is now quite awake,

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: not. And I am afraid, afraid, afraid!--I am afraid of all things--even

text: _5 November, morning._--Let me be accurate in everything, for though you
title: Dracula

text: and I have seen some strange things together, you may at the first think
title: Dracula

text: that I, Van Helsing, am mad--that the many horrors and the so long
title: Dracula

text: strain on nerves has at the last turn my brain.
title: Dracula

text: All yesterday we travel, ever getting closer to the mountains, and
title: Dracula

text: moving into a more and more wild and desert land. There are great,
title: Dracula

text: frowning precipices and much falling water, and Nature seem to have held
title: Dracula

text: sometime her carnival. Madam Mina still sleep and sleep; and though I
title: Dracula

text: did have hunger and appeased it, I could not waken her--even for food. I
title: Dracula

text: began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was upon her, tainted as
title: Dracula

text: she is with that Vampire baptism. "Well," said I to myself, "if it be
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

text: of in his diary. At once I exulted and feared; for now, for good or ill,
title: Dracula

text: I woke Madam Mina, and again tried to hypnotise her; but alas!
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
